         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2447" data-file-width="3922" height="137" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/Mohonk_Mountain_House_2011_View_of_Mohonk_Guest_Rooms_from_One_Hiking_Trail_FRD_3205.jpg/220px-Mohonk_Mountain_House_2011_View_of_Mohonk_Guest_Rooms_from_One_Hiking_Trail_FRD_3205.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/Mohonk_Mountain_House_2011_View_of_Mohonk_Guest_Rooms_from_One_Hiking_Trail_FRD_3205.jpg/330px-Mohonk_Mountain_House_2011_View_of_Mohonk_Guest_Rooms_from_One_Hiking_Trail_FRD_3205.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/Mohonk_Mountain_House_2011_View_of_Mohonk_Guest_Rooms_from_One_Hiking_Trail_FRD_3205.jpg/440px-Mohonk_Mountain_House_2011_View_of_Mohonk_Guest_Rooms_from_One_Hiking_Trail_FRD_3205.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mohonk_Mountain_House_2011_View_of_Mohonk_Guest_Rooms_from_One_Hiking_Trail_FRD_3205.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a href="/wiki/Mohonk_Mountain_House" title="Mohonk Mountain House">
          Mohonk Mountain House
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/Ulster_County,_New_York" title="Ulster County, New York">
          Ulster County
         </a>
         , New York, in the Hudson Valley, was designated a
         <a href="/wiki/National_Historic_Landmark" title="National Historic Landmark">
          National Historic Landmark
         </a>
         in 1986.
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-55">
          <a href="#cite_note-55">
           [55]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sugarloaf_Hill_Hudson_Highlands_from_Bear_Mountain_Bridge.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="274" data-file-width="398" height="151" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/Sugarloaf_Hill_Hudson_Highlands_from_Bear_Mountain_Bridge.JPG/220px-Sugarloaf_Hill_Hudson_Highlands_from_Bear_Mountain_Bridge.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/Sugarloaf_Hill_Hudson_Highlands_from_Bear_Mountain_Bridge.JPG/330px-Sugarloaf_Hill_Hudson_Highlands_from_Bear_Mountain_Bridge.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/8/82/Sugarloaf_Hill_Hudson_Highlands_from_Bear_Mountain_Bridge.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Sugarloaf_Hill_Hudson_Highlands_from_Bear_Mountain_Bridge.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Sugarloaf_Hill_(Putnam_County,_New_York)" title="Sugarloaf Hill (Putnam County, New York)">
          Sugarloaf Hill
         </a>
         in
         <a href="/wiki/Putnam_County,_New_York" title="Putnam County, New York">
          Putnam County
         </a>
         , New York, in the
         <a href="/wiki/Hudson_Valley" title="Hudson Valley">
          Hudson Valley
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Lower_Hudson_Valley">
        Lower Hudson Valley
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York_metropolitan_area&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: Lower Hudson Valley">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Hudson_Valley" title="Hudson Valley">
        Hudson Valley
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Known for its
       <a href="/wiki/Topography" title="Topography">
        hilly terrain
       </a>
       , picturesque settings, and quaint small towns and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Village_(New_York)" title="Village (New York)">
        villages
       </a>
       , the Lower Hudson Valley is centered around the
       <a href="/wiki/Hudson_River" title="Hudson River">
        Hudson River
       </a>
       north of New York City and lies within New York State. Its two most populous counties,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Westchester_County" title="Westchester County">
        Westchester
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rockland_County" title="Rockland County">
        Rockland
       </a>
       , are located on the eastern and western sides of the river, respectively, connected by the heavily trafficked
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_Tappan_Zee_Bridge" title="New Tappan Zee Bridge">
        New Tappan Zee Bridge
       </a>
       (a major commuter route from Rockland County towards New York City) as well as the
       <a href="/wiki/Bear_Mountain_Bridge" title="Bear Mountain Bridge">
        Bear Mountain Bridge
       </a>
       near their northern ends. Several branches of the MTA Metro-North Railroad serve the region's rail commuters.
       <a href="/wiki/Southern_Westchester" title="Southern Westchester">
        Southern Westchester County
       </a>
       contains more densely populated areas and includes the cities of Yonkers, Mount Vernon, New Rochelle, and White Plains. Although many of the suburban communities of Westchester are known for their affluence and expense (some examples: Scarsdale, Chappaqua, Armonk, Katonah, and Briarcliff Manor), the Lower Hudson Valley as a whole is one of the fastest-growing areas in the metropolitan area because of high housing costs in New York City and the inner suburbs.
      </p>
      <p>
       Historically, the valley was home to many factories, including paper mills, but a significant number have closed. After years of lingering pollution, cleanup efforts to improve the Hudson River water quality are currently planned and will be supervised by the
       <a href="/wiki/United_States_Environmental_Protection_Agency" title="United States Environmental Protection Agency">
        United States Environmental Protection Agency
       </a>
       (EPA).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EPA_56-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-EPA-56">
         [56]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Mid-Hudson_Valley">
        Mid-Hudson Valley
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York_metropolitan_area&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11" title="Edit section: Mid-Hudson Valley">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       The Mid-Hudson Valley region of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/State_of_New_York" title="State of New York">
        State of New York
       </a>
       is midway between the state capital of
       <a href="/wiki/Albany,_New_York" title="Albany, New York">
        Albany
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_York_City,_New_York" title="New York City, New York">
        New York City
       </a>
       . The area includes the counties of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dutchess_County" title="Dutchess County">
        Dutchess
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ulster_County" title="Ulster County">
        Ulster
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Orange_County,_New_York" title="Orange County, New York">
        Orange
       </a>
       . The main cities being
       <a href="/wiki/Newburgh,_New_York" title="Newburgh, New York">
        Newburgh
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Poughkeepsie,_New_York" title="Poughkeepsie, New York">
        Poughkeepsie
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Beacon,_New_York" title="Beacon, New York">
        Beacon
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Kingston,_New_York" title="Kingston, New York">
        Kingston
       </a>
       . The area is home to many quaint villages known for natural beauty and great restaurants. There are many outdoor activities, as well. The
       <a href="/wiki/Walkway_over_the_Hudson" title="Walkway over the Hudson">
        Walkway over the Hudson
       </a>
       , which is one of the longest footbridges in the world, crosses the
       <a href="/wiki/Hudson_River" title="Hudson River">
        Hudson River
       </a>
       connecting
       <a href="/wiki/Poughkeepsie,_New_York" title="Poughkeepsie, New York">
        Poughkeepsie
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Highland,_Ulster_County,_New_York" title="Highland, Ulster County, New York">
        Highland
       </a>
       . The 13 mile-long
       <a href="/wiki/Dutchess_Rail_Trail" title="Dutchess Rail Trail">
        Dutchess Rail Trail
       </a>
       streches from
       <a href="/wiki/Hopewell_Junction,_New_York" title="Hopewell Junction, New York">
        Hopewell Junction
       </a>
       to the beginning of the Walkway over the Hudson in Poughkeepsie. The area is home to the
       <a href="/wiki/Wappingers_Central_School_District" title="Wappingers Central School District">
        Wappingers Central School District
       </a>
       , which the second largest school district in the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/State_of_New_York" title="State of New York">
        state of New York
       </a>
       . The Newburgh Waterfront in the City of
       <a href="/wiki/Newburgh,_New_York" title="Newburgh, New York">
        Newburgh
       </a>
       is home to many high-end restaurants. The City of
       <a href="/wiki/Beacon,_New_York" title="Beacon, New York">
        Beacon
       </a>
       is home to many neat eateries and shops.
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/U.S._Route_9" title="U.S. Route 9">
        U.S. Route 9
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Interstate_84_(Pennsylvania%E2%80%93Massachusetts)" title="Interstate 84 (Pennsylvania–Massachusetts)">
        I-84
       </a>
       , and the
       <a href="/wiki/Taconic_State_Parkway" title="Taconic State Parkway">
        Taconic State Parkway
       </a>
       all run through Dutchess County.
       <a href="/wiki/Metro-North_Railroad" title="Metro-North Railroad">
        Metro-North Railroad
       </a>
       train station,
       <a href="/wiki/New_Hamburg,_New_York" title="New Hamburg, New York">
        New Hamburg
       </a>
       , is located in the Town of
       <a href="/wiki/Poughkeepsie,_New_York" title="Poughkeepsie, New York">
        Poughkeepsie
       </a>
       and runs from
       <a href="/wiki/Poughkeepsie,_New_York" title="Poughkeepsie, New York">
        Poughkeepsie
       </a>
       to
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Grand_Central_Station" title="Grand Central Station">
        Grand Central Station
       </a>
       in
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_York_City,_New_York" title="New York City, New York">
        New York City
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Western_Connecticut">
        Western Connecticut
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York_metropolitan_area&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" title="Edit section: Western Connecticut">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:MohawkMountain.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="300" data-file-width="400" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/MohawkMountain.jpg/220px-MohawkMountain.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/MohawkMountain.jpg/330px-MohawkMountain.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/52/MohawkMountain.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:MohawkMountain.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Mohawk_Mountain_Ski_Area" title="Mohawk Mountain Ski Area">
          Mohawk Mountain Ski Area
         </a>
         in
         <a href="/wiki/Cornwall,_Connecticut" title="Cornwall, Connecticut">
          Cornwall
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/Litchfield_County,_Connecticut" title="Litchfield County, Connecticut">
          Litchfield County, Connecticut
         </a>
         , in the
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Berkshire_Mountains" title="Berkshire Mountains">
          Berkshire Mountains
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Fairfield_County,_Connecticut" title="Fairfield County, Connecticut">
        Fairfield County, Connecticut
       </a>
       ;
       <a href="/wiki/New_Haven_County,_Connecticut" title="New Haven County, Connecticut">
        New Haven County, Connecticut
       </a>
       ; and
       <a href="/wiki/Litchfield_County,_Connecticut" title="Litchfield County, Connecticut">
        Litchfield County, Connecticut
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Fairfield, New Haven, and Litchfield Counties are in western Connecticut. Large business and
       <a href="/wiki/Industrial_park" title="Industrial park">
        industrial parks
       </a>
       are scattered throughout the area, though mostly contained within Fairfield County. The three counties (and Connecticut in general) are known for affluence. Geographically, the areas are flat along the coast with low hills eventually giving way to larger hills such as
       <a href="/wiki/The_Berkshires" title="The Berkshires">
        The Berkshires
       </a>
       further inland, to the
       <a href="/wiki/Massachusetts" title="Massachusetts">
        Massachusetts
       </a>
       border. Most of the largest cities in the state are located within New Haven County (home to
       <a href="/wiki/Yale_University" title="Yale University">
        Yale University
       </a>
       ) and Fairfield County.
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span id="Monroe_and_Pike_Counties.2C_Pennsylvania">
       </span>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Monroe_and_Pike_Counties,_Pennsylvania">
        Monroe and Pike Counties, Pennsylvania
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York_metropolitan_area&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13" title="Edit section: Monroe and Pike Counties, Pennsylvania">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Dingmansfalls.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1000" data-file-width="755" height="291" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Dingmansfalls.jpg/220px-Dingmansfalls.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Dingmansfalls.jpg/330px-Dingmansfalls.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Dingmansfalls.jpg/440px-Dingmansfalls.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Dingmansfalls.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Dingmans_Falls" title="Dingmans Falls">
          Dingmans Falls
         </a>
         in the
         <a href="/wiki/Delaware_Water_Gap_National_Recreation_Area" title="Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area">
          Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/Pike_County,_Pennsylvania" title="Pike County, Pennsylvania">
          Pike County
         </a>
         , northeastern Pennsylvania.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Monroe_County,_Pennsylvania" title="Monroe County, Pennsylvania">
        Monroe County, Pennsylvania
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Pike_County,_Pennsylvania" title="Pike County, Pennsylvania">
        Pike County, Pennsylvania
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Pike County is located in
       <a href="/wiki/Northeastern_Pennsylvania" title="Northeastern Pennsylvania">
        northeastern Pennsylvania
       </a>
       . As of the 2010 Census, the population was 57,369.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-57">
        <a href="#cite_note-57">
         [57]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Its
       <a href="/wiki/County_seat" title="County seat">
        county seat
       </a>
       is
       <a href="/wiki/Milford,_Pennsylvania" title="Milford, Pennsylvania">
        Milford
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58">
        <a href="#cite_note-58">
         [58]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Part of the
       <a href="/wiki/Pocono_Mountains" title="Pocono Mountains">
        Pocono Mountains
       </a>
       region lies within Pike County, which has ranked among the fastest-growing counties of Pennsylvania.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-59">
        <a href="#cite_note-59">
         [59]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Monroe County was added to the CMSA in March 2013, as was the Lehigh Valley. Monroe's county seat is
       <a href="/wiki/Stroudsburg,_Pennsylvania" title="Stroudsburg, Pennsylvania">
        Stroudsburg
       </a>
       , and its largest borough is
       <a href="/wiki/East_Stroudsburg,_Pennsylvania" title="East Stroudsburg, Pennsylvania">
        East Stroudsburg
       </a>
       . Monroe and Pike are the fastest-growing counties in Pennsylvania and are home to many residents who commute to jobs in Northern New Jersey and New York City. They are located largely in the
       <a href="/wiki/Pocono_Mountains" title="Pocono Mountains">
        Pocono Mountains
       </a>
       and have multiple state parks as well as most of the Pennsylvania portion of the
       <a href="/wiki/Delaware_Water_Gap_National_Recreation_Area" title="Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area">
        Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area
       </a>
       . Efforts continue to resume passenger rail service on the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lackawanna_Cutoff" title="Lackawanna Cutoff">
        Lackawanna Cutoff
       </a>
       route between
       <a href="/wiki/Scranton,_Pennsylvania" title="Scranton, Pennsylvania">
        Scranton
       </a>
       and Northern New Jersey via Monroe County.
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Lehigh_Valley">
        Lehigh Valley
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York_metropolitan_area&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14" title="Edit section: Lehigh Valley">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main articles:
       <a href="/wiki/Carbon_County,_Pennsylvania" title="Carbon County, Pennsylvania">
        Carbon County, Pennsylvania
       </a>
       ;
       <a href="/wiki/Lehigh_County,_Pennsylvania" title="Lehigh County, Pennsylvania">
        Lehigh County, Pennsylvania
       </a>
       ;
       <a href="/wiki/Northampton_County,_Pennsylvania" title="Northampton County, Pennsylvania">
        Northampton County, Pennsylvania
       </a>
       ; and
       <a href="/wiki/Warren_County,_New_Jersey" title="Warren County, New Jersey">
        Warren County, New Jersey
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       The Allentown-Bethlehem-Easton MSA (better known as the
       <a href="/wiki/Lehigh_Valley" title="Lehigh Valley">
        Lehigh Valley
       </a>
       ) consists of Carbon, Lehigh, and Northampton counties. It constitutes the third-largest metropolitan area of Pennsylvania, and
       <a href="/wiki/Allentown,_Pennsylvania" title="Allentown, Pennsylvania">
        Allentown
       </a>
       is the state's third-largest city. The region is important for east-west transportation between New York City, northern and central New Jersey, the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Harrisburg_metropolitan_area" title="Harrisburg metropolitan area">
        Harrisburg metropolitan area
       </a>
       , and points west, both by rail and
       <a href="/wiki/Interstate_78" title="Interstate 78">
        Interstate 78
       </a>
       . It is also critical for north-south road traffic via
       <a href="/wiki/Interstate_476" title="Interstate 476">
        Interstate 476
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Pennsylvania_Route_33" title="Pennsylvania Route 33">
        Route 33 Expressway
       </a>
       . The Lehigh Valley is in the process of major urban economic redevelopment, including development of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Logistics_industry" title="Logistics industry">
        logistics industry
       </a>
       as well as the Two Rivers Landing in downtown
       <a href="/wiki/Easton,_Pennsylvania" title="Easton, Pennsylvania">
        Easton
       </a>
       , the Steel Stacks/Sands complex on the south side of
       <a href="/wiki/Bethlehem,_Pennsylvania" title="Bethlehem, Pennsylvania">
        Bethlehem
       </a>
       , and a
       <a href="/wiki/PPL_Center" title="PPL Center">
        multi-purpose arena
       </a>
       (which hosted its first event on September 12, 2014) in downtown Allentown. In 2010 the population was 712,481 for the PA portion and 821,173 in the MSA as a whole. While a large portion of Carbon County is in the
       <a href="/wiki/Pocono_Mountains" title="Pocono Mountains">
        Pocono Mountains
       </a>
       , it is also in the
       <a href="/wiki/Lehigh_River" title="Lehigh River">
        Lehigh River
       </a>
       valley and the employment interchange is mainly with
       <a href="/wiki/Lehigh_County,_Pennsylvania" title="Lehigh County, Pennsylvania">
        Lehigh
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Northampton_County,_Pennsylvania" title="Northampton County, Pennsylvania">
        Northampton
       </a>
       Counties.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Urban_areas_of_the_region">
        Urban areas of the region
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York_metropolitan_area&amp;action=edit&amp;section=15" title="Edit section: Urban areas of the region">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:StamfordCTRRstaLookingNE11112007.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1704" data-file-width="2272" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/StamfordCTRRstaLookingNE11112007.jpg/220px-StamfordCTRRstaLookingNE11112007.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/StamfordCTRRstaLookingNE11112007.jpg/330px-StamfordCTRRstaLookingNE11112007.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/StamfordCTRRstaLookingNE11112007.jpg/440px-StamfordCTRRstaLookingNE11112007.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:StamfordCTRRstaLookingNE11112007.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Downtown_Stamford" title="Downtown Stamford">
          Downtown Stamford
         </a>
         in
         <a href="/wiki/Fairfield_County,_Connecticut" title="Fairfield County, Connecticut">
          Fairfield County, Connecticut
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:NewHavenCT_Green.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="336" data-file-width="520" height="142" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/NewHavenCT_Green.jpg/220px-NewHavenCT_Green.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/NewHavenCT_Green.jpg/330px-NewHavenCT_Green.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/NewHavenCT_Green.jpg/440px-NewHavenCT_Green.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:NewHavenCT_Green.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_Haven_Green_Historic_District" title="New Haven Green Historic District">
          New Haven Green Historic District
         </a>
         in Connecticut was designated a
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/National_Historic_Landmark_District" title="National Historic Landmark District">
          National Historic Landmark District
         </a>
         in 1970.
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-60">
          <a href="#cite_note-60">
           [60]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb noresize tnone" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right:auto; overflow:hidden; width:auto; max-width:1608px;">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="">
        <div class="overflowbugx" style="overflow:auto;">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Fullnycskyline.jpg" title="Skyline of New York City and Jersey City from Newark, New Jersey, seen prior to completion of One World Trade Center in Lower Manhattan.">
          <img alt="" data-file-height="536" data-file-width="3600" height="238" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Fullnycskyline.jpg/1600px-Fullnycskyline.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Fullnycskyline.jpg/2400px-Fullnycskyline.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Fullnycskyline.jpg/3200px-Fullnycskyline.jpg 2x" width="1600"/>
         </a>
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption" style="text-align:center">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Fullnycskyline.jpg" title="File:Fullnycskyline.jpg">
          </a>
         </div>
         Skyline of
         <a href="/wiki/New_York_City" title="New York City">
          New York City
         </a>
         and
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jersey_City" title="Jersey City">
          Jersey City
         </a>
         from
         <a href="/wiki/Newark,_New_Jersey" title="Newark, New Jersey">
          Newark, New Jersey
         </a>
         , seen prior to completion of
         <a href="/wiki/One_World_Trade_Center" title="One World Trade Center">
          One World Trade Center
         </a>
         in
         <a href="/wiki/Lower_Manhattan" title="Lower Manhattan">
          Lower Manhattan
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The combined statistical area is a multicore metropolitan region containing several urban areas.
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Newark_aerial_looking_northwest.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="864" data-file-width="660" height="288" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Newark_aerial_looking_northwest.jpg/220px-Newark_aerial_looking_northwest.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Newark_aerial_looking_northwest.jpg/330px-Newark_aerial_looking_northwest.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Newark_aerial_looking_northwest.jpg/440px-Newark_aerial_looking_northwest.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Newark_aerial_looking_northwest.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Aerial view of
         <a href="/wiki/Newark,_New_Jersey" title="Newark, New Jersey">
          Newark
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/Essex_County,_New_Jersey" title="Essex County, New Jersey">
          Essex County
         </a>
         , New Jersey's most populous city.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Yonkers_Public_Library_02.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3904" data-file-width="5909" height="145" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Yonkers_Public_Library_02.JPG/220px-Yonkers_Public_Library_02.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Yonkers_Public_Library_02.JPG/330px-Yonkers_Public_Library_02.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Yonkers_Public_Library_02.JPG/440px-Yonkers_Public_Library_02.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Yonkers_Public_Library_02.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Yonkers_Public_Library" title="Yonkers Public Library">
          Public Library
         </a>
         in
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Yonkers" title="Yonkers">
          Yonkers
         </a>
         , Westchester County, New York.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Barnum_Museum,_Bridgeport.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="880" data-file-width="768" height="252" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Barnum_Museum%2C_Bridgeport.jpg/220px-Barnum_Museum%2C_Bridgeport.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Barnum_Museum%2C_Bridgeport.jpg/330px-Barnum_Museum%2C_Bridgeport.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Barnum_Museum%2C_Bridgeport.jpg/440px-Barnum_Museum%2C_Bridgeport.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Barnum_Museum,_Bridgeport.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Barnum_Museum" title="Barnum Museum">
          Barnum Museum
         </a>
         in
         <a href="/wiki/Bridgeport,_Connecticut" title="Bridgeport, Connecticut">

         </a>
         , Fairfield County, Connecticut's most populous city.
        </div>

      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Downtown-paterson-nj2.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="555" data-file-width="818" height="149" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Downtown-paterson-nj2.jpg/220px-Downtown-paterson-nj2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Downtown-paterson-nj2.jpg/330px-Downtown-paterson-nj2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Downtown-paterson-nj2.jpg/440px-Downtown-paterson-nj2.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Downtown-paterson-nj2.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Paterson,_New_Jersey" title="Paterson, New Jersey">
          Paterson
         </a>
         , Passaic County, New Jersey, known as the "Silk City",
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-61">
          <a href="#cite_note-61">
           [61]
          </a>
         </sup>
         seen here from
         <a href="/wiki/Garret_Mountain_Reservation" title="Garret Mountain Reservation">
          Garret Mountain Reservation
         </a>
         , is a prime destination for a diverse pool of international
         <a href="/wiki/Immigration" title="Immigration">
          immigrants
         </a>
         .
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62">
          <a href="#cite_note-62">
           [62]
          </a>
         </sup>
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-63">
          <a href="#cite_note-63">
           [63]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:2007_-_700_Block_Hamilton_Street_North_Side.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1646" data-file-width="2615" height="138" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/2007_-_700_Block_Hamilton_Street_North_Side.jpg/220px-2007_-_700_Block_Hamilton_Street_North_Side.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/2007_-_700_Block_Hamilton_Street_North_Side.jpg/330px-2007_-_700_Block_Hamilton_Street_North_Side.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/2007_-_700_Block_Hamilton_Street_North_Side.jpg/440px-2007_-_700_Block_Hamilton_Street_North_Side.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:2007_-_700_Block_Hamilton_Street_North_Side.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Allentown,_Pennsylvania" title="Allentown, Pennsylvania">
          Allentown
         </a>
         in
         <a href="/wiki/Lehigh_County,_Pennsylvania" title="Lehigh County, Pennsylvania">
          Lehigh County
         </a>
         is Pennsylvania's largest city within the New York metropolitan area.

      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Main_cities">
        Main cities
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York_metropolitan_area&amp;action=edit&amp;section=16" title="Edit section: Main cities">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       The following is a list of "principal cities" and their respective population estimates from the 2010 U.S. Census Bureau publication. Principal cities are generally those where there is a greater number of jobs than employed residents.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-64">

        </a>

      </p>

      <div style="clear:both;">
      </div>
      <div class="thumb noresize tnone" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right:auto; overflow:hidden; width:auto; max-width:808px;">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="">
        <div class="overflowbugx" style="overflow:auto;">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Manhattan_from_Weehawken,_NJ.jpg" title="Midtown Manhattan from Weehawken, New Jersey">
          <img alt="" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="4335" height="221" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Manhattan_from_Weehawken%2C_NJ.jpg/800px-Manhattan_from_Weehawken%2C_NJ.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Manhattan_from_Weehawken%2C_NJ.jpg/1200px-Manhattan_from_Weehawken%2C_NJ.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Manhattan_from_Weehawken%2C_NJ.jpg/1600px-Manhattan_from_Weehawken%2C_NJ.jpg 2x" width="800"/>
         </a>
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Manhattan_from_Weehawken,_NJ.jpg" title="File:Manhattan from Weehawken, NJ.jpg">
          </a>
         </div>
         Midtown Manhattan from Weehawken, New Jersey
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">
        Climate
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York_metropolitan_area&amp;action=edit&amp;section=17" title="Edit section: Climate">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       Under the
       <a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="Köppen climate classification">
        Köppen climate classification
       </a>
       , using the 0 °C (32 °F) January
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Isotherm_(contour_line)" title="Isotherm (contour line)">
        isotherm
       </a>
       , New York City, western (and parts of eastern) Long Island, and a sliver of the Jersey Shore experience a
       <a href="/wiki/Humid_subtropical_climate" title="Humid subtropical climate">
        humid subtropical climate
       </a>
       (
       <i>
        Cfa
       </i>
       ),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Peel,_M._C.;_Finlayson,_B._L.;_McMahon,_T._A_68-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Peel,_M._C.;_Finlayson,_B._L.;_McMahon,_T._A-68">
         [68]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-newyorkpolonia.com_69-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-newyorkpolonia.com-69">
         [69]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and New York is thus the northernmost major city on the North American continent with this climate type.
      </p>
      <p>
       Much of the remainder of the metropolitan area lies in the transition zone from a humid subtropical (
       <i>
        Cfa
       </i>
       ) to a
       <a href="/wiki/Humid_continental_climate" title="Humid continental climate">
        humid continental climate
       </a>
       (
       <i>
        Dfa
       </i>
       ),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Peel,_M._C.;_Finlayson,_B._L.;_McMahon,_T._A_68-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Peel,_M._C.;_Finlayson,_B._L.;_McMahon,_T._A-68">
         [68]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-newyorkpolonia.com_69-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-newyorkpolonia.com-69">
         [69]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and it is only the inland, more exurban areas far to the north and west such as Sussex County, New Jersey, that have a January daily average of −3 °C (26.6 °F) or below and are fully humid continental; the
       <i>
        Dfb
       </i>
       (warm summer subtype) regime is only found inland at a higher elevation,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Peel,_M._C.;_Finlayson,_B._L.;_McMahon,_T._A_68-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-Peel,_M._C.;_Finlayson,_B._L.;_McMahon,_T._A-68">
         [68]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and receives greater snowfall
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-70">
        <a href="#cite_note-70">
         [70]
        </a>
       </sup>
       than the
       <i>
        Dfa
       </i>
       region. Carbon, Monroe, and Pike Counties in Pennsylvania also have a fully humid continental climate, as do colder areas of Lehigh and Northampton Counties.
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Oceanic_climate" title="Oceanic climate">
        oceanic climate
       </a>
       zone (
       <i>
        Cfb
       </i>
       ) only exists on the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/North_Fork,_Suffolk_County,_New_York" title="North Fork, Suffolk County, New York">
        North Fork
       </a>
       , islands in
       <a href="/wiki/Peconic_Bay" title="Peconic Bay">
        Peconic Bay
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Fishers_Island,_New_York" title="Fishers Island, New York">
        Fishers Island
       </a>
       . It is rare in eastern North America.
      </p>
      <p>
       Winters are cold and damp, and prevailing wind patterns that blow offshore temper the moderating effects of the Atlantic Ocean; yet the Atlantic and the partial shielding by the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Appalachians" title="Appalachians">
        Appalachians
       </a>
       from colder air keep the New York area warmer in the winter than inland North American metropolitan areas located at similar or lesser latitudes including
       <a href="/wiki/Pittsburgh" title="Pittsburgh">
        Pittsburgh
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Cincinnati" title="Cincinnati">
        Cincinnati
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Indianapolis" title="Indianapolis">
        Indianapolis
       </a>
       . Warm periods with 50 °F (10 °C)+ temperatures may occasionally occur during winter.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-71">
        <a href="#cite_note-71">
         [71]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Spring and autumn are unpredictable and can range from chilly to warm, although they are usually mild with low humidity. Summers in the area are typically hot and humid. Nighttime conditions in and around the five boroughs of New York City are often exacerbated by the
       <a href="/wiki/Urban_heat_island" title="Urban heat island">
        urban heat island
       </a>
       phenomenon, and temperatures exceed 90 °F (32 °C) on average of 7–8 days (on the immediate
       <a href="/wiki/Long_Island_Sound" title="Long Island Sound">
        Long Island Sound
       </a>
       and Atlantic coasts), up to in excess of 27 days (inland suburbs in New Jersey) each summer and may exceed 100 °F (38 °C).
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (October 2017)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Almost all of the metropolitan area receives at least 42 inches (1,070 mm) of precipitation annually, which is relatively evenly spread throughout the year, and many areas receive upwards of 50 in (1,270 mm). Average winter snowfall for 1981 to 2010 ranges from just under 25 inches (64 cm) along the coast of Long Island to more than 50 in (127 cm) in some inland areas, but this usually varies considerably from year to year.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Weatherbase_New_York,_New_York_72-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Weatherbase_New_York,_New_York-72">
         [72]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Hurricanes and tropical storms are rare in the New York area, but are not unheard of and always have the potential to strike the area, with
       <a href="/wiki/Storm_surge" title="Storm surge">
        storm surge
       </a>
       a major threat in coastal areas and heavy rain (with the danger of flooding) further inland.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73">
        <a href="#cite_note-73">
         [73]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The New York metropolitan area averages 234 days with at least some
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sunshine" title="Sunshine">
        sunshine
       </a>
       and 59% of possible sunlight annually,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Percent_Sunshine_74-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Percent_Sunshine-74">
         [74]
        </a>
       </sup>
       accumulating 2,400 to 2,800 hours of sunshine per annum.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-75">
        <a href="#cite_note-75">
         [75]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <table class="wikitable collapsible collapsed" style="width:90%; text-align:center; font-size:90%; line-height: 1.2em; margin:auto;">

          Central Park
         </a>
         ), 1981–2010 normals,
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-76">

         </sup>

      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="History">
        History
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York_metropolitan_area&amp;action=edit&amp;section=18" title="Edit section: History">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/History_of_New_York_City" title="History of New York City">
        History of New York City
       </a>
      </div>
      <table class="plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-style ambox-Cleanup" role="presentation">
       <tr>
        <td class="mbox-image">
         <div style="width:52px">
          <img alt="" data-file-height="48" data-file-width="48" height="40" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f2/Edit-clear.svg/40px-Edit-clear.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f2/Edit-clear.svg/60px-Edit-clear.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f2/Edit-clear.svg/80px-Edit-clear.svg.png 2x" width="40"/>
         </div>
        </td>
        <td class="mbox-text">
         <div class="mbox-text-span">
          This section may
          <b>
           require
           <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Cleanup" title="Wikipedia:Cleanup">
            cleanup
           </a>
          </b>
          to meet Wikipedia's
          <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style">
           quality standards
          </a>
          . The specific problem is:
          <b>
           grammar, style, citations
          </b>
          <span class="hide-when-compact">
           Please help
           <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=New_York_metropolitan_area&amp;action=edit">
            improve this section
           </a>
           if you can.
          </span>

            (May 2012)
