      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:The_Purchase_of_Manhattan_Island.png">
         <img alt="A pen drawing of two men in 16th-century Dutch clothing presenting an open box of items to a group of Native Americans in feather headdresses stereotypical of plains tribes." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1013" data-file-width="1542" height="145" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/The_Purchase_of_Manhattan_Island.png/220px-The_Purchase_of_Manhattan_Island.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/The_Purchase_of_Manhattan_Island.png/330px-The_Purchase_of_Manhattan_Island.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/The_Purchase_of_Manhattan_Island.png/440px-The_Purchase_of_Manhattan_Island.png 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:The_Purchase_of_Manhattan_Island.png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Peter_Minuit" title="Peter Minuit">
          Peter Minuit
         </a>
         is credited with the purchase of the island of
         <a href="/wiki/Manhattan" title="Manhattan">
          Manhattan
         </a>
         in 1626.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:GezichtOpNieuwAmsterdam.jpg">
         <img alt="A painting of a coastline dotted with red roof houses and a windmill, with several masted ships sailing close to shore under blue sky." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4964" data-file-width="7276" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/GezichtOpNieuwAmsterdam.jpg/220px-GezichtOpNieuwAmsterdam.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/GezichtOpNieuwAmsterdam.jpg/330px-GezichtOpNieuwAmsterdam.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/GezichtOpNieuwAmsterdam.jpg/440px-GezichtOpNieuwAmsterdam.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:GezichtOpNieuwAmsterdam.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/New_Amsterdam" title="New Amsterdam">
          New Amsterdam
         </a>
         , centered in the eventual
         <a href="/wiki/Lower_Manhattan" title="Lower Manhattan">
          Lower Manhattan
         </a>
         , in 1664, the year
         <a href="/wiki/England" title="England">
          England
         </a>
         took control and renamed it "New York".
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mulberry_Street_NYC_c1900_LOC_3g04637u_edit.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2067" data-file-width="2800" height="162" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Mulberry_Street_NYC_c1900_LOC_3g04637u_edit.jpg/220px-Mulberry_Street_NYC_c1900_LOC_3g04637u_edit.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Mulberry_Street_NYC_c1900_LOC_3g04637u_edit.jpg/330px-Mulberry_Street_NYC_c1900_LOC_3g04637u_edit.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Mulberry_Street_NYC_c1900_LOC_3g04637u_edit.jpg/440px-Mulberry_Street_NYC_c1900_LOC_3g04637u_edit.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mulberry_Street_NYC_c1900_LOC_3g04637u_edit.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Little_Italy,_Manhattan" title="Little Italy, Manhattan">
          Little Italy
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/Lower_East_Side" title="Lower East Side">
          Lower East Side
         </a>
         , Manhattan, circa 1900.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:UN_Headquarters_2.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3072" data-file-width="2304" height="293" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/UN_Headquarters_2.jpg/220px-UN_Headquarters_2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/UN_Headquarters_2.jpg/330px-UN_Headquarters_2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/UN_Headquarters_2.jpg/440px-UN_Headquarters_2.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:UN_Headquarters_2.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_Nations_Headquarters" title="United Nations Headquarters">
          United Nations Headquarters
         </a>
         , established in
         <a href="/wiki/Midtown_Manhattan" title="Midtown Manhattan">
          Midtown Manhattan
         </a>
         in 1952.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Liberty-statue-from-below.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1920" data-file-width="2560" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Liberty-statue-from-below.jpg/220px-Liberty-statue-from-below.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Liberty-statue-from-below.jpg/330px-Liberty-statue-from-below.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Liberty-statue-from-below.jpg/440px-Liberty-statue-from-below.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Liberty-statue-from-below.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <i>
          Liberty Enlightening the World
         </i>
         , known as the
         <a href="/wiki/Statue_of_Liberty" title="Statue of Liberty">
          Statue of Liberty
         </a>
         , on
         <a href="/wiki/Liberty_Island" title="Liberty Island">
          Liberty Island
         </a>
         in
         <a href="/wiki/New_York_Harbor" title="New York Harbor">
          New York Harbor
         </a>
         , is a globally recognized symbol of both the United States and ideals such as freedom, democracy, and opportunity.
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-88">
          <a href="#cite_note-88">
           [84]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:368px;max-width:368px">
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:242px;max-width:242px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:WTC_smoking_on_9-11.jpeg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1600" height="180" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/WTC_smoking_on_9-11.jpeg/240px-WTC_smoking_on_9-11.jpeg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/WTC_smoking_on_9-11.jpeg/360px-WTC_smoking_on_9-11.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/WTC_smoking_on_9-11.jpeg/480px-WTC_smoking_on_9-11.jpeg 2x" width="240"/>
          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
          The
          <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Center_(1973%E2%80%932001)" title="World Trade Center (1973–2001)">
           World Trade Center
          </a>
          in
          <a href="/wiki/Lower_Manhattan" title="Lower Manhattan">
           Lower Manhattan
          </a>
          during the
          <a href="/wiki/September_11_attacks" title="September 11 attacks">
           September 11 attacks
          </a>
          in 2001, which caused nearly 3,000 deaths, mostly residents of the metropolitan region.
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:122px;max-width:122px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:OneWorldTradeCenter.jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="1187" data-file-width="788" height="181" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/OneWorldTradeCenter.jpg/120px-OneWorldTradeCenter.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/OneWorldTradeCenter.jpg/180px-OneWorldTradeCenter.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/OneWorldTradeCenter.jpg/240px-OneWorldTradeCenter.jpg 2x" width="120"/>
          </a>
         </div>
         <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
          <a href="/wiki/One_World_Trade_Center" title="One World Trade Center">
           One World Trade Center
          </a>
          , built in its place and opened in 2014.
         </div>
        </div>
        <div style="clear:left">
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       During the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wisconsinan_glaciation" title="Wisconsinan glaciation">
        Wisconsinan glaciation
       </a>
       , the region was situated at the edge of a large
       <a href="/wiki/Ice_sheet" title="Ice sheet">
        ice sheet
       </a>
       over 1000 feet in depth. The ice sheet scraped away large amounts of soil, leaving the
       <a href="/wiki/Bedrock" title="Bedrock">
        bedrock
       </a>
       that serves as the geologic
       <a href="/wiki/Foundation_(engineering)" title="Foundation (engineering)">
        foundation
       </a>
       for much of the New York City metropolitan region today. Later on, the ice sheet would help split apart what are now Long Island and Staten Island.
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Unisfera_Flushing.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2540" data-file-width="3808" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Unisfera_Flushing.jpg/220px-Unisfera_Flushing.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Unisfera_Flushing.jpg/330px-Unisfera_Flushing.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Unisfera_Flushing.jpg/440px-Unisfera_Flushing.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Unisfera_Flushing.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a href="/wiki/Unisphere" title="Unisphere">
          Unisphere
         </a>
         in
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Flushing_Meadows_%E2%80%93_Corona_Park" title="Flushing Meadows – Corona Park">
          Flushing Meadows – Corona Park
         </a>
         , iconic of
         <a href="/wiki/Queens" title="Queens">
          Queens
         </a>
         , the most
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ethnic_diversity" title="Ethnic diversity">
          ethnically diverse
         </a>
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U.S._county" title="U.S. county">
          U.S. county
         </a>
         and a
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Borough_(New_York_City)" title="Borough (New York City)">
          borough
         </a>
         of New York City.
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-89">
          <a href="#cite_note-89">
           [85]
          </a>
         </sup>
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90">
          <a href="#cite_note-90">
           [86]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       At the time of European contact the region was inhabited by
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Native_American_(U.S._Census)" title="Native American (U.S. Census)">
        Native Americans
       </a>
       , predominantly the
       <a href="/wiki/Lenape" title="Lenape">
        Lenape
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91">
        <a href="#cite_note-91">
         [87]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and others. The Native Americans used the abundant waterways in the area for many purposes, such as fishing and trade routes. Sailing for France in 1524,
       <a href="/wiki/Giovanni_da_Verrazzano" title="Giovanni da Verrazzano">
        Giovanni da Verrazzano
       </a>
       was the first European to enter the local waters and encounter the residents, but he did not make landfall.
       <a href="/wiki/Henry_Hudson" title="Henry Hudson">
        Henry Hudson
       </a>
       , sailing for the Dutch in 1609, visited the area and built a settlement on Lower Manhattan Island that was eventually renamed
       <a href="/wiki/New_Amsterdam" title="New Amsterdam">
        New Amsterdam
       </a>
       by
       <a href="/wiki/Dutch_colonization_of_the_Americas" title="Dutch colonization of the Americas">
        Dutch
       </a>
       colonists in 1626.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-u-s-history.com_92-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-u-s-history.com-92">
         [88]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 1664, the area went under English control,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-u-s-history.com_92-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-u-s-history.com-92">
         [88]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93">
        <a href="#cite_note-93">
         [89]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and was later renamed
       <i>
        New York
       </i>
       after King
       <a href="/wiki/Charles_II_of_England" title="Charles II of England">
        Charles II of England
       </a>
       granted the lands to his brother, the
       <a href="/wiki/James_II_of_England" title="James II of England">
        Duke of York
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94">
        <a href="#cite_note-94">
         [90]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-95">
        <a href="#cite_note-95">
         [91]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       As the fur trade expanded further north, New York became a trading hub, which brought in a diverse set of ethnic groups including
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ethnic_groups_of_Africa" title="Ethnic groups of Africa">
        Africans
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Jews" title="Jews">
        Jews
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_people" title="Portuguese people">
        Portuguese
       </a>
       . The island of Manhattan had an extraordinary natural harbor formed by
       <a href="/wiki/New_York_Bay" title="New York Bay">
        New York Bay
       </a>
       (actually the drowned lower river valley of the Hudson River, enclosed by
       <a href="/wiki/Moraine" title="Moraine">
        glacial moraines
       </a>
       ), the
       <a href="/wiki/East_River" title="East River">
        East River
       </a>
       (actually a
       <a href="/wiki/Strait" title="Strait">
        tidal strait
       </a>
       ), and the
       <a href="/wiki/Hudson_River" title="Hudson River">
        Hudson River
       </a>
       , all of which merge at the southern tip, from which all later development spread. During the
       <a href="/wiki/American_Revolution" title="American Revolution">
        American Revolution
       </a>
       , the strategic waterways made New York vitally important as a wartime base for the British navy. Many battles such as the
       <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Long_Island" title="Battle of Long Island">
        Battle of Long Island
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/New_York_and_New_Jersey_campaign" title="New York and New Jersey campaign">
        Battle of New York
       </a>
       were fought in the region to secure it. New York City was captured by the British early in the war, becoming a haven for
       <a href="/wiki/Loyalist_(American_Revolution)" title="Loyalist (American Revolution)">
        Loyalist
       </a>
       refugees from other parts of the country, and remained in the hands of the British until the war ended in 1783. New York served as the
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_capitals_in_the_United_States#Former_national_capitals" title="List of capitals in the United States">
        capital of the United States
       </a>
       from 1785 until 1790,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-senate_96-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-senate-96">
         [92]
        </a>
       </sup>
       after which the capital moved to Philadelphia. New York City has been the country's largest city since 1790.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-97">
        <a href="#cite_note-97">
         [93]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 1792, the
       <a href="/wiki/Buttonwood_Agreement" title="Buttonwood Agreement">
        Buttonwood Agreement
       </a>
       , made by a group of merchants, created what is now the
       <a href="/wiki/New_York_Stock_Exchange" title="New York Stock Exchange">
        New York Stock Exchange
       </a>
       in Lower Manhattan. Today, many people in the metropolitan area work in this important stock exchange.
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Statue_of_Liberty" title="Statue of Liberty">
        Statue of Liberty
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/New_York_Harbor" title="New York Harbor">
        New York Harbor
       </a>
       greeted millions of
       <a href="/wiki/Immigration" title="Immigration">
        immigrants
       </a>
       as they came to America by ship in the late 19th and early 20th centuries
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-98">
        <a href="#cite_note-98">
         [94]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and is a globally recognized symbol of the United States and its
       <a href="/wiki/Democracy" title="Democracy">
        democracy
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-99">
        <a href="#cite_note-99">
         [95]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Large-scale immigration into New York was a result of a large demand for manpower. A
       <a href="/wiki/Cosmopolitanism" title="Cosmopolitanism">
        cosmopolitan
       </a>
       attitude in the city created tolerance for various cultures and ethnic groups. German, Irish, and Italian immigrants were among the largest ethnic groups. Today, many of their descendants continue to live in the region. Cultural buildings such as the
       <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_Museum_of_Art" title="Metropolitan Museum of Art">
        Metropolitan Museum of Art
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_Opera" title="Metropolitan Opera">
        Metropolitan Opera
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/American_Museum_of_Natural_History" title="American Museum of Natural History">
        American Museum of Natural History
       </a>
       were built. New York newspapers were read around the country as media moguls
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/James_Gordon_Bennett,_Sr." title="James Gordon Bennett, Sr.">
        James Gordon Bennett, Sr.
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Pulitzer" title="Joseph Pulitzer">
        Joseph Pulitzer
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/William_Randolph_Hearst" title="William Randolph Hearst">
        William Randolph Hearst
       </a>
       battled for readership. In 1884, over 70% of exports passed through ports in New York or in one of the surrounding towns. The five
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Borough_(New_York_City)" title="Borough (New York City)">
        boroughs
       </a>
       of New York City —
       <a href="/wiki/The_Bronx" title="The Bronx">
        The Bronx
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Brooklyn" title="Brooklyn">
        Brooklyn
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Manhattan" title="Manhattan">
        Manhattan
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Queens" title="Queens">
        Queens
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Staten_Island" title="Staten Island">
        Staten Island
       </a>
       — were consolidated into a single city in 1898.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-100">
        <a href="#cite_note-100">
         [96]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101">
        <a href="#cite_note-101">
         [97]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The newly unified New York City encouraged both more physical connections between the boroughs and the growth of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bedroom_community" title="Bedroom community">
        bedroom communities
       </a>
       . The
       <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Subway" title="New York City Subway">
        New York City Subway
       </a>
       began operating in 1904 as the
       <a href="/wiki/Interborough_Rapid_Transit_Company" title="Interborough Rapid Transit Company">
        Interborough Rapid Transit Company
       </a>
       , one of three systems (the other two being the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brooklyn-Manhattan_Transit_Corporation" title="Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit Corporation">
        Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit Corporation
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Independent_Subway_System" title="Independent Subway System">
        Independent Subway System
       </a>
       ) that were later taken over by the city. Railroad stations such as
       <a href="/wiki/Grand_Central_Terminal" title="Grand Central Terminal">
        Grand Central Terminal
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Pennsylvania_Station_(New_York_City)" title="Pennsylvania Station (New York City)">
        Pennsylvania Station
       </a>
       helped fuel suburban growth. During the era of the
       <a href="/wiki/Prohibition" title="Prohibition">
        Prohibition
       </a>
       , when alcohol was banned nationwide, organized crime grew to supply the high demand for bootleg alcohol. The Broadway
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Theater_District" title="Theater District">
        Theater District
       </a>
       developed with the showing of the musical,
       <a href="/wiki/Show_Boat" title="Show Boat">
        Show Boat
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Great_Depression" title="Great Depression">
        Great Depression
       </a>
       suspended the region's fortunes as a period of widespread unemployment and poverty began. City planner
       <a href="/wiki/Robert_Moses" title="Robert Moses">
        Robert Moses
       </a>
       began his automobile-centered career of building bridges,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Parkways" title="Parkways">
        parkways
       </a>
       , and later
       <a href="/wiki/Controlled-access_highway" title="Controlled-access highway">
        expressways
       </a>
       . During World War II, the city economy was hurt by blockades of German
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U-Boats" title="U-Boats">
        U-Boats
       </a>
       , which limited shipping with Europe.
      </p>
      <p>
       After its population peaked in 1950, much of the city's population began leaving for the
       <a href="/wiki/Suburb" title="Suburb">
        suburbs
       </a>
       of New York City. The effects were a result of
       <a href="/wiki/White_flight" title="White flight">
        white flight
       </a>
       . Industry and commerce also declined in this era, with businesses leaving for the suburbs and other cities. The city, particularly Brooklyn, was dealt a psychological as well as an economic blow with the loss of the iconic
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brooklyn_Dodgers" title="Brooklyn Dodgers">
        Brooklyn Dodgers
       </a>
       major-league
       <a href="/wiki/Baseball" title="Baseball">
        baseball
       </a>
       team, which moved to
       <a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles" title="Los Angeles">
        Los Angeles
       </a>
       after the 1957 season. Crime affected the city severely. Urban renewal projects alleviated the decay in Midtown Manhattan to a certain extent, but later failed. There was little reported social disruption during the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Northeast_Blackout_of_1965" title="Northeast Blackout of 1965">
        Northeast Blackout of 1965
       </a>
       , but the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_York_City_Blackout_of_1977" title="New York City Blackout of 1977">
        New York City Blackout of 1977
       </a>
       caused massive rioting in some parts of the city. A rare highlight was the completion of the former
       <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Center_(1973%E2%80%932001)" title="World Trade Center (1973–2001)">
        World Trade Center
       </a>
       , which once stood as the tallest buildings in the world.
      </p>
      <p>
       In the 1980s, the city economy was booming.
       <a href="/wiki/Wall_Street" title="Wall Street">
        Wall Street
       </a>
       was fueling an economic surge in the real estate market. Despite this, crime was still an issue. Beginning in the 1990s, however, crime dropped substantially.
       <a href="/wiki/Crime_in_New_York_City" title="Crime in New York City">
        Crime in New York City
       </a>
       has continued to decline through the 21st century.
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Hurricane_Sandy_Flooding_Avenue_C_2012.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2848" data-file-width="4288" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Hurricane_Sandy_Flooding_Avenue_C_2012.JPG/220px-Hurricane_Sandy_Flooding_Avenue_C_2012.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Hurricane_Sandy_Flooding_Avenue_C_2012.JPG/330px-Hurricane_Sandy_Flooding_Avenue_C_2012.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Hurricane_Sandy_Flooding_Avenue_C_2012.JPG/440px-Hurricane_Sandy_Flooding_Avenue_C_2012.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Hurricane_Sandy_Flooding_Avenue_C_2012.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         A flooded
         <a href="/wiki/Avenue_C_(Manhattan)" title="Avenue C (Manhattan)">
          Avenue C
         </a>
         in Manhattan just moments before the explosion at an
         <a href="/wiki/Electrical_substation" title="Electrical substation">
          electrical substation
         </a>
         caused by
         <a href="/wiki/Hurricane_Sandy" title="Hurricane Sandy">
          Hurricane Sandy
         </a>
         on October 29, 2012.
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-102">
          <a href="#cite_note-102">
           [98]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       A major event in the region's and the nation's history was the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/September_11th_attacks" title="September 11th attacks">
        September 11th attacks
       </a>
       in 2001, which killed nearly 3,000 people as two planes crashed into the former World Trade Center and caused the towers to collapse. Businesses led an exodus from Lower Manhattan because of this but were replaced by an increased number of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/High-rise" title="High-rise">
        high-rise
       </a>
       residences. In 2003, another blackout occurred, the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2003_North_America_blackout" title="2003 North America blackout">
        2003 North America blackout
       </a>
       , but the city suffered no looting and a building boom in New York City continues to this day.
      </p>
      <p>
       On October 29 and 30, 2012,
       <a href="/wiki/Hurricane_Sandy" title="Hurricane Sandy">
        Hurricane Sandy
       </a>
       caused extensive destruction in the metropolitan area, ravaging portions of the Atlantic coastline with record-high
       <a href="/wiki/Storm_surge" title="Storm surge">
        storm surge
       </a>
       , severe flooding, and high winds, causing
       <a href="/wiki/Power_outage" title="Power outage">
        power outages
       </a>
       for millions of residents via downed trees and power lines and malfunctions at
       <a href="/wiki/Electrical_substation" title="Electrical substation">
        electrical substations
       </a>
       , leading to
       <a href="/wiki/Gasoline" title="Gasoline">
        gasoline
       </a>
       shortages and snarling
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mass_transit" title="Mass transit">
        mass transit
       </a>
       systems. Damage to New York and New Jersey in terms of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Physical_infrastructure" title="Physical infrastructure">
        physical infrastructure
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Private_property" title="Private property">
        private property
       </a>
       as well as including interrupted commerce was estimated at several tens of billions of dollars.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-103">
        <a href="#cite_note-103">
         [99]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The storm and its profound impacts have prompted the discussion of constructing
       <a href="/wiki/Seawall" title="Seawall">
        seawalls
       </a>
       and other coastal barriers around the shorelines of the metropolitan area to minimize the risk of destructive consequences from another such event in the future.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-104">
        <a href="#cite_note-104">
         [100]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-105">
        <a href="#cite_note-105">
         [101]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div style="clear:both;">
      </div>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Statistical_history">
        Statistical history
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York_metropolitan_area&amp;action=edit&amp;section=19" title="Edit section: Statistical history">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U.S._Census_Bureau" title="U.S. Census Bureau">
        U.S. Census Bureau
       </a>
       first designated metropolitan areas in 1950 as
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Metropolitan_Statistical_Area" title="Metropolitan Statistical Area">
        standard metropolitan areas
       </a>
       (SMAs). The "New York–Northeastern NJ SMA" was defined to include 17 counties: 9 in New York (the five boroughs of New York City, Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester, and Rockland) and 8 in New Jersey (Bergen, Hudson, Passaic, Essex, Union, Morris, Somerset, and Middlesex). In 1960, the metropolitan area standards were modified and renamed standard metropolitan statistical areas (SMSAs). The new standards resulted in the splitting of the former SMA into several pieces: the nine New York counties became the "New York SMSA"; three of the New Jersey counties (Essex, Union, and Morris) became the "Newark SMSA"; two other New Jersey counties (Bergen and Passaic) became the "Paterson–Passaic–Clifton SMSA"; Hudson County was designated the "Jersey City SMSA"; and Middlesex and Somerset counties lost their metropolitan status. In 1973, a new set of metropolitan area standards resulted in further changes: Nassau and Suffolk counties were split off as their own SMSA ("Nassau–Suffolk SMSA"); Bergen County (originally part of the Paterson–Clifton–Passaic SMSA) was transferred to the New York SMSA; the New York SMSA also received Putnam County (previously non-metropolitan); Somerset County was added to the Newark SMSA; and two new SMSAs, the "New Brunswick–Perth Amboy–Sayreville SMSA" (Middlesex County) and "Long Branch–Asbury Park SMSA" (Monmouth County), were established. In 1983, the concept of a consolidated metropolitan statistical area (CMSA) was first implemented. A CMSA consisted of several primary metropolitan statistical areas (PMSAs), which were individual employment centers within a wider
       <a href="/wiki/Labor_market_area" title="Labor market area">
        labor market area
       </a>
       . The "New York–Northern New Jersey–Long Island CMSA" consisted of 12 PMSAs. Seven PMSAs were based on the original 1950 New York SMA that were split up: New York, Bergen–Passaic, Jersey City, Middlesex–Somerset–Hunterdon (Hunterdon added for the first time), Monmouth–Ocean (Ocean added for the first time), Nassau–Suffolk, and Newark (Sussex added for the first time). One additional PMSA was the Orange County PMSA (previously the Newburgh–Middletown SMSA). The other four PMSAs were former SMSAs in Connecticut: Bridgeport, Stamford, Norwalk, and Danbury. In 1993, four PMSAs were added to the New York–Northern New Jersey–Long Island CMSA: Trenton PMSA (Mercer County), Dutchess County PMSA, Waterbury PMSA, and New Haven PMSA. Several new counties were also added to the CMSA: Sussex, Warren, and Pike. The CMSA model was originally utilized for tabulating data from the 2000 census. In 2003, a new set of standards was established using the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Core_based_statistical_area" title="Core based statistical area">
        Core Based Statistical Area (CBSA)
       </a>
       model was adopted and remains in use as of 2010. The CBSA model resulted in the splitting up of the old CMSA into several metropolitan statistical areas: New York–Northern New Jersey–Long Island, Poughkeepsie–Newburgh–Middletown, Trenton–Ewing, Bridgeport–Stamford–Norwalk (includes Danbury), and New Haven–Milford (includes Waterbury). In 2013, the Census Bureau added Carbon, Lehigh, Northampton, and Monroe counties in Pennsylvania, and Warren County, New Jersey (encompassing collectively the Allentown-Bethlehem-Easton, PA-NJ MSA and the East Stroudsburg, PA MSA), to the Combined Statistical Area,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-106">
        <a href="#cite_note-106">
         [102]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and assimilated Poughkeepsie–Newburgh–Middletown into the larger New York–Northern New Jersey–Long Island–NY–NJ–PA MSA.
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">
        Demographics
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>

        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>

        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Dragon_in_Chinatown_NYC_Lunar_New_Year.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Chinatown,_Manhattan" title="Chinatown, Manhattan">
          Chinatown, Manhattan (紐約華埠)
         </a>
         . The New York City metropolitan area is home to the largest population of
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chinese_Americans_in_New_York_City" title="Chinese Americans in New York City">
          overseas Chinese
         </a>
         outside of
         <a href="/wiki/Asia" title="Asia">
          Asia
         </a>
         , over three-quarters of a million in 2013.
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYCLargestChinesePopulation_107-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-NYCLargestChinesePopulation-107">
           [103]
          </a>
         </sup>
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-queensbuzz_108-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-queensbuzz-108">
           [104]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Broad_Avenue_Palisades_Park.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2304" data-file-width="3072" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Broad_Avenue_Palisades_Park.jpg/220px-Broad_Avenue_Palisades_Park.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Broad_Avenue_Palisades_Park.jpg/330px-Broad_Avenue_Palisades_Park.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Broad_Avenue_Palisades_Park.jpg/440px-Broad_Avenue_Palisades_Park.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Broad_Avenue_Palisades_Park.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Bergen_County,_New_Jersey#Korean_American" title="Bergen County, New Jersey">
          Bergen County (버겐 카운티)
         </a>
         , New Jersey, is home to
         <a href="/wiki/List_of_U.S._cities_with_significant_Korean-American_populations#Top_ten_municipalities_as_ranked_by_Korean-American_percentage_of_overall_population_in_2010" title="List of U.S. cities with significant Korean-American populations">
          all of the nation's top ten municipalities by percentage of Korean population
         </a>
         , led by
         <a href="/wiki/Koreatown,_Palisades_Park" title="Koreatown, Palisades Park">
          Palisades Park (벼랑 공원)
         </a>
         (above), a
         <a href="/wiki/Borough_(New_Jersey)" title="Borough (New Jersey)">
          borough
         </a>
         where
         <a href="/wiki/Koreans" title="Koreans">
          Koreans
         </a>
         comprise the majority (52%) of the population.
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-109">
          <a href="#cite_note-109">
           [105]
          </a>
         </sup>
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110">
          <a href="#cite_note-110">
           [106]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">

      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
