      </center>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">
        Economy
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York_metropolitan_area&amp;action=edit&amp;section=24" title="Edit section: Economy">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_New_York_City" title="Economy of New York City">
        Economy of New York City
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Cold_Spring_Harbor_Laboratory.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="263" data-file-width="400" height="145" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/Cold_Spring_Harbor_Laboratory.jpg/220px-Cold_Spring_Harbor_Laboratory.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/Cold_Spring_Harbor_Laboratory.jpg/330px-Cold_Spring_Harbor_Laboratory.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/8/82/Cold_Spring_Harbor_Laboratory.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Cold_Spring_Harbor_Laboratory.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Cold_Spring_Harbor_Laboratory" title="Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory">
          Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory
         </a>
         on the
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gold_Coast_(Long_Island)" title="Gold Coast (Long Island)">
          North Shore
         </a>
         of Long Island is an internationally renowned
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Biomedical_research" title="Biomedical research">
          biomedical research
         </a>
         facility and home to eight scientists awarded the
         <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Physiology_or_Medicine" title="Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine">
          Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The New York City regional economy is the largest in the United States and one of the most important in the world. In 2015 the CSA had a GDP of $1.83 trillion, which would rank 8th among countries. Many
       <a href="/wiki/Fortune_500" title="Fortune 500">
        Fortune 500
       </a>
       corporations are
       <a href="/wiki/Headquarters" title="Headquarters">
        headquartered
       </a>
       in New York City,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-155">
        <a href="#cite_note-155">
         [151]
        </a>
       </sup>
       as are a large number of
       <a href="/wiki/Foreign_corporation" title="Foreign corporation">
        foreign corporations
       </a>
       . One out of ten
       <a href="/wiki/Private_sector" title="Private sector">
        private sector
       </a>
       jobs in the city is with a foreign company.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-156">
        <a href="#cite_note-156">
         [152]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 2012 and 2015, New York City topped the first and second
       <i>
        Global Economic Power Index
       </i>
       lists, respectively, as published by
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/The_Atlantic" title="The Atlantic">
         The Atlantic
        </a>
       </i>
       , with cities ranked according to criteria reflecting their presence on five different lists as published by five separate entities.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EconomicallyPowerful2015_157-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-EconomicallyPowerful2015-157">
         [153]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-158">
        <a href="#cite_note-158">
         [154]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Finance, international trade, new and traditional media, real estate, education, fashion and entertainment, tourism, biotechnology, and manufacturing are the leading industries in the area.
      </p>
      <p>
       Along with its wealth, the area has a
       <a href="/wiki/Cost_of_living" title="Cost of living">
        cost of living
       </a>
       that is among the highest in the United States.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-159">
        <a href="#cite_note-159">
         [155]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Photos_NewYork1_032.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="768" data-file-width="1024" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Photos_NewYork1_032.jpg/220px-Photos_NewYork1_032.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Photos_NewYork1_032.jpg/330px-Photos_NewYork1_032.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Photos_NewYork1_032.jpg/440px-Photos_NewYork1_032.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Photos_NewYork1_032.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a href="/wiki/New_York_Stock_Exchange" title="New York Stock Exchange">
          New York Stock Exchange
         </a>
         on
         <a href="/wiki/Wall_Street" title="Wall Street">
          Wall Street
         </a>
         , the world's largest stock exchange per total
         <a href="/wiki/Market_capitalization" title="Market capitalization">
          market capitalization
         </a>
         of its listed companies.
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYSElargest_160-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-NYSElargest-160">
           [156]
          </a>
         </sup>
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYSEhighestcap_161-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-NYSEhighestcap-161">
           [157]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Wall_Street">
        Wall Street
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York_metropolitan_area&amp;action=edit&amp;section=25" title="Edit section: Wall Street">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Wall_Street" title="Wall Street">
        Wall Street
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       New York City's most important economic sector lies in its role as the
       <a href="/wiki/Headquarters" title="Headquarters">
        headquarters
       </a>
       for the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Financial_center" title="Financial center">
        U.S. financial industry
       </a>
       , metonymously known as
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Wall_Street" title="Wall Street">
         Wall Street
        </a>
       </i>
       . Anchored by Wall Street, in the
       <a href="/wiki/Financial_District,_Manhattan" title="Financial District, Manhattan">
        Financial District
       </a>
       of
       <a href="/wiki/Lower_Manhattan" title="Lower Manhattan">
        Lower Manhattan
       </a>
       , New York City has been called both the most economically powerful city and the leading financial center of the world,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EconomicallyPowerful2015_157-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-EconomicallyPowerful2015-157">
         [153]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-162">
        <a href="#cite_note-162">
         [158]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-163">
        <a href="#cite_note-163">
         [159]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-164">
        <a href="#cite_note-164">
         [160]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-165">
        <a href="#cite_note-165">
         [161]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and the city is home to the world's two
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_stock_exchanges" title="List of stock exchanges">
        largest stock exchanges
       </a>
       by total
       <a href="/wiki/Market_capitalization" title="Market capitalization">
        market capitalization
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/New_York_Stock_Exchange" title="New York Stock Exchange">
        New York Stock Exchange
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/NASDAQ" title="NASDAQ">
        NASDAQ
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYSElargest_160-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-NYSElargest-160">
         [156]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYSEhighestcap_161-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-NYSEhighestcap-161">
         [157]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The city's
       <a href="/wiki/Security_(finance)" title="Security (finance)">
        securities
       </a>
       industry, enumerating 163,400 jobs in August 2013, continues to form the largest segment of the city's financial sector and an important economic engine, accounting in 2012 for 5 percent of the city's
       <a href="/wiki/Private_sector" title="Private sector">
        private sector
       </a>
       jobs, 8.5 percent (US$3.8 billion) of its tax revenue, and 22 percent of the city's total wages, including an average salary of US$360,700.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-166">
        <a href="#cite_note-166">
         [162]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Manhattan had approximately 520 million square feet (48.1 million m²) of office space in 2013,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-167">
        <a href="#cite_note-167">
         [163]
        </a>
       </sup>
       making it the largest office market in the United States,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-168">
        <a href="#cite_note-168">
         [164]
        </a>
       </sup>
       while
       <a href="/wiki/Midtown_Manhattan" title="Midtown Manhattan">
        Midtown Manhattan
       </a>
       is the largest
       <a href="/wiki/Central_business_district" title="Central business district">
        central business district
       </a>
       in the nation.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-169">
        <a href="#cite_note-169">
         [165]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Lower Manhattan is the third largest central business district in the United States and is home to both the New York Stock Exchange, on Wall Street, and the
       <a href="/wiki/NASDAQ" title="NASDAQ">
        NASDAQ
       </a>
       , at
       <a href="/wiki/One_Liberty_Plaza" title="One Liberty Plaza">
        165 Broadway
       </a>
       , representing the world's largest and second largest stock exchanges, respectively, when measured both by overall average daily trading volume and by total
       <a href="/wiki/Market_capitalization" title="Market capitalization">
        market capitalization
       </a>
       of their listed companies in 2013.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYSEhighestcap_161-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-NYSEhighestcap-161">
         [157]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Wall Street
       <a href="/wiki/Investment_banking" title="Investment banking">
        investment banking
       </a>
       fees in 2012 totaled approximately US$40 billion,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-170">
        <a href="#cite_note-170">
         [166]
        </a>
       </sup>
       while in 2013, senior New York City bank officers who manage
       <a href="/wiki/Risk_management" title="Risk management">
        risk and compliance
       </a>
       functions earned as much as US$324,000 annually.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-171">
        <a href="#cite_note-171">
         [167]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In July 2013,
       <a href="/wiki/NYSE_Euronext" title="NYSE Euronext">
        NYSE Euronext
       </a>
       , the operator of the New York Stock Exchange, took over the administration of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/London_interbank_offered_rate" title="London interbank offered rate">
        London interbank offered rate
       </a>
       from the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_Bankers_Association" title="British Bankers Association">
        British Bankers Association
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-172">
        <a href="#cite_note-172">
         [168]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Many Wall Street firms have added or moved auxiliary financial or technical operations into
       <a href="/wiki/Jersey_City,_New_Jersey" title="Jersey City, New Jersey">
        Jersey City
       </a>
       , to take advantage of New Jersey's relatively lower
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Commercial_real_estate" title="Commercial real estate">
        commercial real estate
       </a>
       and rental prices, while offering continued geographic proximity to Manhattan's financial industry ecosystem.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-173">
        <a href="#cite_note-173">
         [169]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Flatiron_District.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1146" data-file-width="1749" height="144" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Flatiron_District.jpg/220px-Flatiron_District.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Flatiron_District.jpg/330px-Flatiron_District.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Flatiron_District.jpg/440px-Flatiron_District.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Flatiron_District.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Manhattan's
         <a href="/wiki/Flatiron_District" title="Flatiron District">
          Flatiron District
         </a>
         was the cradle of Silicon Alley, now
         <a href="/wiki/Metonymy" title="Metonymy">
          metonymous
         </a>
         for the New York metropolitan region's
         <a href="/wiki/High_tech" title="High tech">
          high tech
         </a>
         sector, which has since expanded beyond the area.
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-174">
          <a href="#cite_note-174">
           [170]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Silicon_Alley">
        Silicon Alley
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York_metropolitan_area&amp;action=edit&amp;section=26" title="Edit section: Silicon Alley">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Silicon_Alley" title="Silicon Alley">
        Silicon Alley
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Further information:
       <a href="/wiki/Tech_companies_in_the_New_York_metropolitan_area" title="Tech companies in the New York metropolitan area">
        Tech companies in the New York metropolitan area
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Biotech_and_pharmaceutical_companies_in_the_New_York_metropolitan_area" title="Biotech and pharmaceutical companies in the New York metropolitan area">
        Biotech and pharmaceutical companies in the New York metropolitan area
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Silicon Alley, centered in New York City, has evolved into a
       <a href="/wiki/Metonymy" title="Metonymy">
        metonym
       </a>
       for the sphere encompassing the metropolitan region's high technology industries
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-175">
        <a href="#cite_note-175">
         [171]
        </a>
       </sup>
       involving the
       <a href="/wiki/Internet" title="Internet">
        Internet
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/New_media" title="New media">
        new media
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Financial_technology" title="Financial technology">
        financial technology
       </a>
       (
       <i>
        fintech
       </i>
       ),
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Telecommunications" title="Telecommunications">
        telecommunications
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Digital_media" title="Digital media">
        digital media
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Software_development" title="Software development">
        software development
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Biotechnology" title="Biotechnology">
        biotechnology
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Game_design" title="Game design">
        game design
       </a>
       , and other fields within
       <a href="/wiki/Information_technology" title="Information technology">
        information technology
       </a>
       that are supported by its
       <a href="/wiki/Entrepreneurship_ecosystem" title="Entrepreneurship ecosystem">
        entrepreneurship ecosystem
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Venture_capital" title="Venture capital">
        venture capital
       </a>
       investments. In 2015, Silicon Alley generated over US$7.3 billion in venture capital investment,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-VentureCapitalNY1_176-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-VentureCapitalNY1-176">
         [172]
        </a>
       </sup>
       most based in Manhattan, as well as in Brooklyn,
       <a href="/wiki/Queens" title="Queens">
        Queens
       </a>
       , and elsewhere in the region. High technology
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Startup_companies" title="Startup companies">
        startup companies
       </a>
       and employment are growing in New York City and across the metropolitan region, bolstered by the city's emergence as a global node of
       <a href="/wiki/Innovation" title="Innovation">
        creativity
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Entrepreneurship" title="Entrepreneurship">
        entrepreneurship
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-VentureCapitalNY1_176-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-VentureCapitalNY1-176">
         [172]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Social_tolerance" title="Social tolerance">
        social tolerance
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SocialToleranceNY1_177-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-SocialToleranceNY1-177">
         [173]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Sustainability" title="Sustainability">
        environmental sustainability
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EnvironmentalSustainabilityNY1_178-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-EnvironmentalSustainabilityNY1-178">
         [174]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EnvironmentalSustainabilityNY2_179-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-EnvironmentalSustainabilityNY2-179">
         [175]
        </a>
       </sup>
       as well as New York's position as the leading Internet hub and telecommunications center in North America, including its vicinity to several
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Transatlantic_telephone_cable" title="Transatlantic telephone cable">
        transatlantic fiber optic trunk lines
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-180">
        <a href="#cite_note-180">
         [176]
        </a>
       </sup>
       the city's
       <a href="/wiki/Intellectual_capital" title="Intellectual capital">
        intellectual capital
       </a>
       , and its extensive outdoor
       <a href="/wiki/Wireless_network" title="Wireless network">
        wireless connectivity
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-181">
        <a href="#cite_note-181">
         [177]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Verizon_Communications" title="Verizon Communications">
        Verizon Communications
       </a>
       , headquartered at 140
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/West_Street_(Manhattan)" title="West Street (Manhattan)">
        West Street
       </a>
       in Lower Manhattan, was at the final stages in 2014 of completing a US$3 billion
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fiberoptic_communication" title="Fiberoptic communication">
        fiberoptic telecommunications
       </a>
       upgrade throughout New York City.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-182">
        <a href="#cite_note-182">
         [178]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Butler_Library_-_1000px_-_AC.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="664" data-file-width="1000" height="166" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Butler_Library_-_1000px_-_AC.jpg/250px-Butler_Library_-_1000px_-_AC.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Butler_Library_-_1000px_-_AC.jpg/375px-Butler_Library_-_1000px_-_AC.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Butler_Library_-_1000px_-_AC.jpg/500px-Butler_Library_-_1000px_-_AC.jpg 2x" width="250"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Butler_Library_-_1000px_-_AC.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Butler_Library" title="Butler Library">
          Butler Library
         </a>
         at
         <a href="/wiki/Columbia_University" title="Columbia University">
          Columbia University
         </a>
         , described as one of the most beautiful college libraries in the United States.
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-183">
          <a href="#cite_note-183">
           [179]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The biotechnology sector is also growing in the New York metropolitan region, based upon its strength in academic scientific
       <a href="/wiki/Research" title="Research">
        research
       </a>
       and public and commercial financial support. On December 19, 2011, then Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York City announced his choice of
       <a href="/wiki/Cornell_University" title="Cornell University">
        Cornell University
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Technion-Israel_Institute_of_Technology" title="Technion-Israel Institute of Technology">
        Technion-Israel Institute of Technology
       </a>
       to build a US$2 billion
       <a href="/wiki/Graduate_school" title="Graduate school">
        graduate school
       </a>
       of
       <a href="/wiki/Applied_science" title="Applied science">
        applied sciences
       </a>
       on
       <a href="/wiki/Roosevelt_Island" title="Roosevelt Island">
        Roosevelt Island
       </a>
       , Manhattan with the goal of transforming New York City into the world's premier technology capital.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-184">
        <a href="#cite_note-184">
         [180]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-185">
        <a href="#cite_note-185">
         [181]
        </a>
       </sup>
       By mid-2014, Accelerator, a biotech
       <a href="/wiki/Investment" title="Investment">
        investment
       </a>
       firm, had raised more than US$30 million from
       <a href="/wiki/Investor" title="Investor">
        investors
       </a>
       , including
       <a href="/wiki/Eli_Lilly_and_Company" title="Eli Lilly and Company">
        Eli Lilly and Company
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Pfizer" title="Pfizer">
        Pfizer
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Johnson_%26_Johnson" title="Johnson &amp; Johnson">
        Johnson &amp; Johnson
       </a>
       , for initial funding to create biotechnology
       <a href="/wiki/Startup_company" title="Startup company">
        startups
       </a>
       at the Alexandria Center for Life Science, which encompasses more than 700,000 square feet (65,000 m
       <sup>
        2
       </sup>
       ) on
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/29th_Street_(Manhattan)" title="29th Street (Manhattan)">
        East 29th Street
       </a>
       and promotes collaboration among scientists and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Entrepreneur" title="Entrepreneur">
        entrepreneurs
       </a>
       at the center and with nearby academic, medical, and research institutions. The
       <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Economic_Development_Corporation" title="New York City Economic Development Corporation">
        New York City Economic Development Corporation
       </a>
       's Early Stage Life Sciences Funding Initiative and venture capital partners, including
       <a href="/wiki/Celgene" title="Celgene">
        Celgene
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/General_Electric" title="General Electric">
        General Electric
       </a>
       Ventures, and Eli Lilly, committed a minimum of US$100 million to help launch 15 to 20 ventures in
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Life_sciences" title="Life sciences">
        life sciences
       </a>
       and biotechnology.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-186">
        <a href="#cite_note-186">
         [182]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Westchester_County,_New_York" title="Westchester County, New York">
        Westchester County
       </a>
       has also developed a burgeoning biotechnology sector in the 21st century, with over US$1 billion in planned private investment as of 2016,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-187">
        <a href="#cite_note-187">
         [183]
        </a>
       </sup>
       earning the county the nickname
       <i>
        Biochester
       </i>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-188">
        <a href="#cite_note-188">
         [184]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Harkness_Tower,_high_contrast.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3241" data-file-width="2592" height="250" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Harkness_Tower%2C_high_contrast.jpg/200px-Harkness_Tower%2C_high_contrast.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Harkness_Tower%2C_high_contrast.jpg/300px-Harkness_Tower%2C_high_contrast.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Harkness_Tower%2C_high_contrast.jpg/400px-Harkness_Tower%2C_high_contrast.jpg 2x" width="200"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Harkness_Tower,_high_contrast.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The bronze clock on
         <a href="/wiki/Harkness_Tower" title="Harkness Tower">
          Harkness Tower
         </a>
         at
         <a href="/wiki/Yale_University" title="Yale University">
          Yale University
         </a>
         , a structure reflecting the
         <a href="/wiki/Collegiate_Gothic" title="Collegiate Gothic">
          Collegiate Gothic
         </a>
         architectural genre.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:ClevelandTowerWatercolor20060829.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2592" data-file-width="1944" height="267" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/ClevelandTowerWatercolor20060829.jpg/200px-ClevelandTowerWatercolor20060829.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/ClevelandTowerWatercolor20060829.jpg/300px-ClevelandTowerWatercolor20060829.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/ClevelandTowerWatercolor20060829.jpg/400px-ClevelandTowerWatercolor20060829.jpg 2x" width="200"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:ClevelandTowerWatercolor20060829.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Watercolor of
         <a href="/wiki/Cleveland_Tower" title="Cleveland Tower">
          Cleveland Tower
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/Princeton_University" title="Princeton University">
          Princeton University
         </a>
         , seen in the noon autumn sun.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:NYU%27s_Bobst_library-2.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="800" data-file-width="600" height="267" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/NYU%27s_Bobst_library-2.jpg/200px-NYU%27s_Bobst_library-2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/NYU%27s_Bobst_library-2.jpg/300px-NYU%27s_Bobst_library-2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/NYU%27s_Bobst_library-2.jpg/400px-NYU%27s_Bobst_library-2.jpg 2x" width="200"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:NYU%27s_Bobst_library-2.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         A view of the interior of the
         <a href="/wiki/Elmer_Holmes_Bobst_Library" title="Elmer Holmes Bobst Library">
          Elmer Holmes Bobst Library
         </a>
         at
         <a href="/wiki/New_York_University" title="New York University">
          New York University
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Port_of_New_York_and_New_Jersey">
        Port of New York and New Jersey
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York_metropolitan_area&amp;action=edit&amp;section=27" title="Edit section: Port of New York and New Jersey">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Port_of_New_York_and_New_Jersey" title="Port of New York and New Jersey">
        Port of New York and New Jersey
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       The Port of New York and New Jersey is the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Port_district" title="Port district">
        port district
       </a>
       of the New York metropolitan area, encompassing the region within approximately a 25-mile (40 km) radius of the
       <a href="/wiki/Statue_of_Liberty_National_Monument" title="Statue of Liberty National Monument">
        Statue of Liberty National Monument
       </a>
       . A major economic engine for the New York metropolitan area, the
       <a href="/wiki/Port" title="Port">
        port
       </a>
       includes the system of navigable waterways in the
       <a href="/wiki/Estuary" title="Estuary">
        estuary
       </a>
       along 650 miles (1,050 km) of shoreline in the vicinity of New York City and the
       <a href="/wiki/Gateway_Region" title="Gateway Region">
        Gateway Region
       </a>
       of northeastern New Jersey, as well as the
       <a href="/wiki/Aviation_in_the_New_York_metropolitan_area" title="Aviation in the New York metropolitan area">
        region's airports
       </a>
       and supporting rail and roadway distribution networks. In 2010, 4,811 ships entered the harbor carrying over 32.2 million metric tons of
       <a href="/wiki/Cargo" title="Cargo">
        cargo
       </a>
       valued at over $175 billion.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-189">
        <a href="#cite_note-189">
         [185]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The port handled $208 billion in shipping cargo in 2011. Approximately 3,200,000
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Twenty-foot_equivalent_units" title="Twenty-foot equivalent units">
        TEUs
       </a>
       of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Container_terminal" title="Container terminal">
        containers
       </a>
       and 700,000 automobiles are handled per year.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-190">
        <a href="#cite_note-190">
         [186]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In the first half of 2014, the port handled 1,583,449 containers, a 35,000-container increase above the six-month record set in 2012,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-191">
        <a href="#cite_note-191">
         [187]
        </a>
       </sup>
       while the port handled a monthly record of 306,805 containers in October 2014.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-192">
        <a href="#cite_note-192">
         [188]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Water_purity_and_availability">
        Water purity and availability
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York_metropolitan_area&amp;action=edit&amp;section=28" title="Edit section: Water purity and availability">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Further information:
       <a href="/wiki/Food_and_water_in_New_York_City" title="Food and water in New York City">
        Food and water in New York City
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_water_supply_system" title="New York City water supply system">
        New York City water supply system
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Water purity and availability are a lifeline for the New York City metropolitan region. New York City is supplied with drinking water by the protected
       <a href="/wiki/Catskill_Mountains" title="Catskill Mountains">
        Catskill Mountains
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Drainage_basin" title="Drainage basin">
        watershed
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-193">
        <a href="#cite_note-193">
         [189]
        </a>
       </sup>
       As a result of the watershed's integrity and undisturbed
       <a href="/wiki/Water_purification" title="Water purification">
        natural water filtration system
       </a>
       , New York is one of only four major cities in the United States the majority of whose drinking water is pure enough not to require purification by
       <a href="/wiki/Water_treatment" title="Water treatment">
        water treatment
       </a>
       plants.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-194">
        <a href="#cite_note-194">
         [190]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Croton_Falls_Reservoir" title="Croton Falls Reservoir">
        Croton Watershed
       </a>
       north of the city is undergoing construction of a US$3.2 billion water purification plant to augment New York City's water supply by an estimated 290 million gallons daily, representing a greater than 20% addition to the city's current availability of water.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-195">
        <a href="#cite_note-195">
         [191]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The ongoing expansion of
       <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Water_Tunnel_No._3" title="New York City Water Tunnel No. 3">
        New York City Water Tunnel No. 3
       </a>
       , an integral part of the New York City water supply system, is the largest capital construction project in the city's history,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-196">
        <a href="#cite_note-196">
         [192]
        </a>
       </sup>
       with segments serving Manhattan and The Bronx completed, and with segments serving Brooklyn and Queens planned for construction in 2020.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-197">
        <a href="#cite_note-197">
         [193]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Much of the fresh water for northern and central New Jersey is provided by
       <a href="/wiki/Reservoir" title="Reservoir">
        reservoirs
       </a>
       , but numerous municipal
       <a href="/wiki/Water_well" title="Water well">
        water wells
       </a>
       exist which accomplish the same purpose.
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Education">
        Education
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York_metropolitan_area&amp;action=edit&amp;section=29" title="Edit section: Education">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <p>
       The New York metropolitan area is home to many prestigious institutions of
       <a href="/wiki/Higher_education" title="Higher education">
        higher education
       </a>
       . Three
       <a href="/wiki/Ivy_League" title="Ivy League">
        Ivy League
       </a>
       universities (
       <a href="/wiki/Columbia_University" title="Columbia University">
        Columbia University
       </a>
       in Manhattan,
       <a href="/wiki/Princeton_University" title="Princeton University">
        Princeton University
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Princeton,_New_Jersey" title="Princeton, New Jersey">
        Princeton, New Jersey
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Yale_University" title="Yale University">
        Yale University
       </a>
       in New Haven, Connecticut – all ranked amongst the top 4 U.S. national universities as per
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/U.S._News_%26_World_Report" title="U.S. News &amp; World Report">
         U.S. News &amp; World Report
        </a>
       </i>
       as of 2013
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-USNewsrankings_198-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-USNewsrankings-198">
         [194]
        </a>
       </sup>
       ) reside in the region,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-199">
        <a href="#cite_note-199">
         [195]
        </a>
       </sup>
       as well as
       <a href="/wiki/New_York_University" title="New York University">
        New York University
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Rockefeller_University" title="The Rockefeller University">
        The Rockefeller University
       </a>
       , both located in Manhattan; all of the above have been ranked amongst the top 35 universities in the world.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-200">
        <a href="#cite_note-200">
         [196]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Rutgers_University" title="Rutgers University">
        Rutgers University
       </a>
       , a global university located 27 miles (43 km) southwest of Manhattan in
       <a href="/wiki/New_Brunswick,_New_Jersey" title="New Brunswick, New Jersey">
        New Brunswick, New Jersey
       </a>
       , is by far the largest university in the region.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-201">
        <a href="#cite_note-201">
         [197]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/New_York_Institute_of_Technology" title="New York Institute of Technology">
        New York Institute of Technology
       </a>
       is located on two campuses, one in Old Westbury,
       <a href="/wiki/Long_Island" title="Long Island">
        Long Island
       </a>
       and one near Columbus Circle in
       <a href="/wiki/Manhattan" title="Manhattan">
        Manhattan
       </a>
       .
       <a href="/wiki/Hofstra_University" title="Hofstra University">
        Hofstra University
       </a>
       is Long Island's largest private university.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-202">
        <a href="#cite_note-202">
         [198]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Fordham_University" title="Fordham University">
        Fordham University
       </a>
       , also a Tier-1 university,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203">
        <a href="#cite_note-203">
         [199]
        </a>
       </sup>
       is the oldest
       <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">
        Catholic
       </a>
       institution of
       <a href="/wiki/Higher_education" title="Higher education">
        higher education
       </a>
       in the
       <a href="/wiki/Northeastern_United_States" title="Northeastern United States">
        northeastern United States
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-204">
        <a href="#cite_note-204">
         [200]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and the third-oldest university in
       <a href="/wiki/New_York_(state)" title="New York (state)">
        New York
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-205">
        <a href="#cite_note-205">
         [201]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In Pennsylvania,
       <a href="/wiki/Lehigh_University" title="Lehigh University">
        Lehigh University
       </a>
       in Bethlehem is among the best universities in the United States. The
       <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Department_of_Education" title="New York City Department of Education">
        New York City Department of Education
       </a>
       is the largest school district in the United States serving over 1.2 million students.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-206">
        <a href="#cite_note-206">
         [202]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The overall region also hosts many public high schools, some of which have been described as among the most prestigious in the country.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-207">
        <a href="#cite_note-207">
         [203]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Attainment">
        Attainment
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York_metropolitan_area&amp;action=edit&amp;section=30" title="Edit section: Attainment">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       According to the 2010
       <a href="/wiki/American_Community_Survey" title="American Community Survey">
        American Community Survey
       </a>
       , of the 14,973,063 persons in this area over 25 years of age, 14.8% (2,216,578) had a graduate or professional degree, 21.1% (3,166,037) had a
       <a href="/wiki/Bachelor%27s_degree" title="Bachelor's degree">
        bachelor's degree
       </a>
       , 6.4% (962,007) had an
       <a href="/wiki/Associate_degree" title="Associate degree">
        associate degree
       </a>
       , 16.0% (2,393,990) had some college education but no degree, 26.8% (4,009,901) had a high school diploma or equivalent, 14.8% (2,224,557) had less than a high school education.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-208">
        <a href="#cite_note-208">
         [204]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 2010, CNN Money ranked the area as one of the top 10 smartest regions in the United States.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-209">
        <a href="#cite_note-209">
         [205]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div style="clear:both;">
      </div>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Transportation">
        Transportation
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York_metropolitan_area&amp;action=edit&amp;section=31" title="Edit section: Transportation">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="mw-stack mobile-float-reset" style="box-sizing: border-box; float:right;">
       <div style="overflow: hidden; margin: 1px;">
        <div class="thumb tright">
         <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:NYC_Subway_R160A_9237_on_the_E.jpg">
           <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="768" data-file-width="1024" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/NYC_Subway_R160A_9237_on_the_E.jpg/220px-NYC_Subway_R160A_9237_on_the_E.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/NYC_Subway_R160A_9237_on_the_E.jpg/330px-NYC_Subway_R160A_9237_on_the_E.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/NYC_Subway_R160A_9237_on_the_E.jpg/440px-NYC_Subway_R160A_9237_on_the_E.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
          </a>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <div class="magnify">
            <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:NYC_Subway_R160A_9237_on_the_E.jpg" title="Enlarge">
            </a>
           </div>
           The
           <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Subway" title="New York City Subway">
            New York City Subway
           </a>
           is the world's largest
           <a href="/wiki/Rapid_transit" title="Rapid transit">
            rapid transit
           </a>
           system by length of routes and by number of
           <a href="/wiki/Train_station" title="Train station">
            stations
           </a>
           .
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="thumb tright">
         <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:PATH_836.JPG">
           <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="768" data-file-width="1024" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/PATH_836.JPG/220px-PATH_836.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/PATH_836.JPG/330px-PATH_836.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/PATH_836.JPG/440px-PATH_836.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
          </a>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <div class="magnify">
            <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:PATH_836.JPG" title="Enlarge">
            </a>
           </div>
           The
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Port_Authority_Trans-Hudson" title="Port Authority Trans-Hudson">
            Port Authority Trans-Hudson (PATH)
           </a>
           rapid transit rail system connects Manhattan and metropolitan
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Northern_New_Jersey" title="Northern New Jersey">
            northern New Jersey
           </a>
           beneath the Hudson River.
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="thumb tright">
         <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Acela_Express_and_Metro-North_railcar.jpg">
           <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1704" data-file-width="2272" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Acela_Express_and_Metro-North_railcar.jpg/220px-Acela_Express_and_Metro-North_railcar.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Acela_Express_and_Metro-North_railcar.jpg/330px-Acela_Express_and_Metro-North_railcar.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Acela_Express_and_Metro-North_railcar.jpg/440px-Acela_Express_and_Metro-North_railcar.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
          </a>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <div class="magnify">
            <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Acela_Express_and_Metro-North_railcar.jpg" title="Enlarge">
            </a>
           </div>
           An
           <a href="/wiki/Acela_Express" title="Acela Express">
            Acela Express
           </a>
           train going to New York City. The Acela Express, operated by
           <a href="/wiki/Amtrak" title="Amtrak">
            Amtrak
           </a>
           through the
           <a href="/wiki/Northeast_Corridor" title="Northeast Corridor">
            Northeast Corridor
           </a>
           , is the sole
           <a href="/wiki/High-speed_rail" title="High-speed rail">
            high-speed rail
           </a>
           service in the country.
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The depth and intricacy of the transportation network in the New York City region parallel the size and complexity of the metropolis itself.
      </p>
      <p>
       In 2013, the New York-Newark-Jersey City metropolitan statistical area (New York City MSA) had the lowest percentage of workers who commuted by private automobile (56.9 percent), with 18.9 percent of area workers traveling via rail transit. During the period starting in 2006 and ending in 2013, the New York City MSA had a 2.2 percent decline of workers commuting by automobile.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-210">
        <a href="#cite_note-210">
         [206]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Rail">
        Rail
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York_metropolitan_area&amp;action=edit&amp;section=32" title="Edit section: Rail">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       About one in every three users of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mass_transit" title="Mass transit">
        mass transit
       </a>
       in the United States and two-thirds of the nation's rail riders live in the New York City metropolitan area.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-211">
        <a href="#cite_note-211">
         [207]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-212">
        <a href="#cite_note-212">
         [208]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="New_York_City_Subway">
        New York City Subway
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York_metropolitan_area&amp;action=edit&amp;section=33" title="Edit section: New York City Subway">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Subway" title="New York City Subway">
        New York City Subway
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Subway" title="New York City Subway">
        New York City Subway
       </a>
       is the largest
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rapid_transit_system" title="Rapid transit system">
        rapid transit system
       </a>
       in the world when measured by stations in operation, with 472, and by length of routes. In 2006 it was the third largest when measured by annual ridership (1.5 billion passenger trips in 2006),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-213">
        <a href="#cite_note-213">
         [209]
        </a>
       </sup>
       However, in 2013, the subway delivered over 1.71 billion rides,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-214">
        <a href="#cite_note-214">
         [210]
        </a>
       </sup>
       but slipped to being the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Metro_systems_by_annual_passenger_rides" title="Metro systems by annual passenger rides">
        seventh busiest rapid transit rail system
       </a>
       in the world.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-215">
        <a href="#cite_note-215">
         [211]
        </a>
       </sup>
       New York's subway is also notable because nearly the entire system remains open 24 hours a day, in contrast to the overnight shutdown common to systems in most cities, including
       <a href="/wiki/MTR" title="MTR">
        Hong Kong
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-216">
        <a href="#cite_note-216">
         [212]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-217">
        <a href="#cite_note-217">
         [213]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/London_Underground" title="London Underground">
        London
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Seoul_Metropolitan_Subway" title="Seoul Metropolitan Subway">
        Seoul
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-218">
        <a href="#cite_note-218">
         [214]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-219">
        <a href="#cite_note-219">
         [215]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tokyo_Subway" title="Tokyo Subway">
        Tokyo
       </a>
       , and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Toronto_Subway_and_RT" title="Toronto Subway and RT">
        Toronto
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Commuter_rail">
        Commuter rail
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York_metropolitan_area&amp;action=edit&amp;section=34" title="Edit section: Commuter rail">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       The metropolitan area is also fundamentally defined by the areas from which people commute into New York City. The city is served by three primary
       <a href="/wiki/Commuter_rail" title="Commuter rail">
        commuter rail
       </a>
       systems plus
       <a href="/wiki/Amtrak" title="Amtrak">
        Amtrak
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Long_Island_Rail_Road" title="Long Island Rail Road">
        Long Island Rail Road
       </a>
       (LIRR), the busiest
       <a href="/wiki/Commuter_rail_in_North_America" title="Commuter rail in North America">
        commuter railroad in the United States
       </a>
       as of 2015,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-APTA-2015-Q4_220-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-APTA-2015-Q4-220">
         [216]
        </a>
       </sup>
       is operated by the
       <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_Transportation_Authority" title="Metropolitan Transportation Authority">
        Metropolitan Transportation Authority
       </a>
       (MTA), an agency of the
       <a href="/wiki/Government_of_New_York_(state)" title="Government of New York (state)">
        State Government of New York
       </a>
       that focuses on New York City-area transit). It has two major terminals at Pennsylvania Station in
       <a href="/wiki/Midtown_Manhattan" title="Midtown Manhattan">
        Midtown Manhattan
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Terminal" title="Atlantic Terminal">
        Atlantic Terminal
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Downtown_Brooklyn" title="Downtown Brooklyn">
        Downtown Brooklyn
       </a>
       , with a minor terminal at the
       <a href="/wiki/Long_Island_City_(LIRR_station)" title="Long Island City (LIRR station)">
        Long Island City
       </a>
       station and a major transfer point at the
       <a href="/wiki/Jamaica_(LIRR_station)" title="Jamaica (LIRR station)">
        Jamaica
       </a>
       station in
       <a href="/wiki/Queens" title="Queens">
        Queens
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_Jersey_Transit_Rail_Operations" title="New Jersey Transit Rail Operations">
        New Jersey Transit
       </a>
       (NJT), the second busiest commuter railroad in the United States as of 2015,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-APTA-2015-Q4_220-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-APTA-2015-Q4-220">
         [216]
        </a>
       </sup>
       is operated by the New Jersey Transit Corporation, an agency of the state of New Jersey, in conjunction with Metro-North Railroad and Amtrak. It has major terminals at Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan, Hoboken Terminal, and
       <a href="/wiki/Pennsylvania_Station_(Newark)" title="Pennsylvania Station (Newark)">
        Newark Pennsylvania Station
       </a>
       , with a major transfer point at
       <a href="/wiki/Secaucus_Junction" title="Secaucus Junction">
        Secaucus Junction
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Hudson_County,_New_Jersey" title="Hudson County, New Jersey">
        Hudson County, New Jersey
       </a>
       . New Jersey Transit also operates the
       <a href="/wiki/Hudson%E2%80%93Bergen_Light_Rail" title="Hudson–Bergen Light Rail">
        Hudson–Bergen Light Rail
       </a>
       through Hudson County, the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Newark_City_Subway" title="Newark City Subway">
        Newark City Subway
       </a>
       , and the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/River_Line_(New_Jersey_Transit)" title="River Line (New Jersey Transit)">
        River Line
       </a>
       that runs along tracks shared with
       <a href="/wiki/Conrail_Shared_Assets_Operations" title="Conrail Shared Assets Operations">
        Conrail Shared Assets Operations
       </a>
       from Trenton to
       <a href="/wiki/Camden,_New_Jersey" title="Camden, New Jersey">
        Camden
       </a>
       in
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Southern_New_Jersey" title="Southern New Jersey">
        southern New Jersey
       </a>
       . NJ Transit also has commuter buses operating in and out of Manhattan.
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Metro-North_Railroad" title="Metro-North Railroad">
        Metro-North Railroad
       </a>
       (MNRR), the third busiest commuter railroad in the United States as of 2015,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-APTA-2015-Q4_220-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-APTA-2015-Q4-220">
         [216]
        </a>
       </sup>
       is also operated by the MTA, in conjunction with the
       <a href="/wiki/Connecticut_Department_of_Transportation" title="Connecticut Department of Transportation">
        Connecticut Department of Transportation
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_Jersey_Transit_Rail_Operations" title="New Jersey Transit Rail Operations">
        New Jersey Transit
       </a>
       . Its major terminal is
       <a href="/wiki/Grand_Central_Terminal" title="Grand Central Terminal">
        Grand Central Terminal
       </a>
       . Trains on the
       <a href="/wiki/Port_Jervis_Line" title="Port Jervis Line">
        Port Jervis Line
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Pascack_Valley_Line" title="Pascack Valley Line">
        Pascack Valley Line
       </a>
       terminate at
       <a href="/wiki/Hoboken_Terminal" title="Hoboken Terminal">
        Hoboken Terminal
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Hoboken,_New_Jersey" title="Hoboken, New Jersey">
        Hoboken, New Jersey
       </a>
       ; commuters may transfer at either
       <a href="/wiki/Secaucus_Junction" title="Secaucus Junction">
        Secaucus Junction
       </a>
       for New Jersey Transit trains to
       <a href="/wiki/Pennsylvania_Station_(New_York_City)" title="Pennsylvania Station (New York City)">
        New York Pennsylvania Station
       </a>
       or at Hoboken Terminal for
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Port_Authority_Trans-Hudson" title="Port Authority Trans-Hudson">
        PATH
       </a>
       trains into Manhattan.
      </p>
      <p>
       Amtrak's
       <a href="/wiki/Northeast_Corridor" title="Northeast Corridor">
        Northeast Corridor
       </a>
       offers service to
       <a href="/wiki/Philadelphia" title="Philadelphia">
        Philadelphia
       </a>
       , New Haven, and other points between and including
       <a href="/wiki/Boston" title="Boston">
        Boston
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Washington,_D.C." title="Washington, D.C.">
        Washington, D.C.
       </a>
       Additionally, the
       <a href="/wiki/Port_Authority_of_New_York_and_New_Jersey" title="Port Authority of New York and New Jersey">
        Port Authority of New York and New Jersey
       </a>
       , an agency controlled by the states of New York and New Jersey, operates the PATH system; this heavy rail transportation service links Manhattan with the counties of Hudson and Essex, New Jersey.
      </p>
      <p>

       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Philadelphia_metropolitan_area" title="Philadelphia metropolitan area">

       </a>
       . (Shown counterclockwise from the Atlantic Ocean):
      </p>

         </a>
        </td>

      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Major_highways">
        Major highways
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York_metropolitan_area&amp;action=edit&amp;section=35" title="Edit section: Major highways">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <table class="plainlinks metadata ambox mbox-small-left ambox-content" role="presentation">
       <tr>
        <td class="mbox-image">
         <img alt="" data-file-height="40" data-file-width="40" height="20" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/20px-Ambox_important.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/30px-Ambox_important.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/40px-Ambox_important.svg.png 2x" width="20"/>
        </td>
        <td class="mbox-text">
         <div class="mbox-text-span">
          This section
          <b>
           is incomplete
          </b>
          .
          <small>
           <i>
            (November 2011)
           </i>
          </small>
         </div>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <p>
       The following highways serve the region:
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:George_Washington_Bridge,_on_a_late_winter_afternoon.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2746" data-file-width="4141" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/George_Washington_Bridge%2C_on_a_late_winter_afternoon.jpg/220px-George_Washington_Bridge%2C_on_a_late_winter_afternoon.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/George_Washington_Bridge%2C_on_a_late_winter_afternoon.jpg/330px-George_Washington_Bridge%2C_on_a_late_winter_afternoon.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/George_Washington_Bridge%2C_on_a_late_winter_afternoon.jpg/440px-George_Washington_Bridge%2C_on_a_late_winter_afternoon.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:George_Washington_Bridge,_on_a_late_winter_afternoon.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a href="/wiki/George_Washington_Bridge" title="George Washington Bridge">
          George Washington Bridge
         </a>
         , connecting
         <a href="/wiki/Washington_Heights,_Manhattan" title="Washington Heights, Manhattan">
          Washington Heights
         </a>
         in Upper Manhattan across the Hudson River to Fort Lee in Bergen County, New Jersey, is the world's busiest motor vehicle bridge.
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-panynj.gov_221-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-panynj.gov-221">
           [217]
          </a>
         </sup>
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-abcgwb_222-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-abcgwb-222">
           [218]
          </a>
         </sup>
         <a href="/wiki/Interstate_95" title="Interstate 95">
          Interstate 95
         </a>
         and
         <a href="/wiki/U.S._Route_1/9" title="U.S. Route 1/9">
          U.S. Route 1/9
         </a>
         cross the river via the bridge, while
         <a href="/wiki/U.S._Route_46" title="U.S. Route 46">
          U.S. Route 46
         </a>
         , which lies entirely within New Jersey, ends halfway across the bridge at the state border with New York.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Walkway_Over_the_Hudson_4.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2592" data-file-width="3872" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Walkway_Over_the_Hudson_4.JPG/220px-Walkway_Over_the_Hudson_4.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Walkway_Over_the_Hudson_4.JPG/330px-Walkway_Over_the_Hudson_4.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Walkway_Over_the_Hudson_4.JPG/440px-Walkway_Over_the_Hudson_4.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Walkway_Over_the_Hudson_4.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Poughkeepsie_Bridge" title="Poughkeepsie Bridge">
          Walkway over the Hudson
         </a>
         , the world's longest
         <a href="/wiki/Pedestrian" title="Pedestrian">
          pedestrian
         </a>
         bridge,
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-guinnessworldrecords.com_223-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-guinnessworldrecords.com-223">
           [219]
          </a>
         </sup>
         connecting
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ulster_County" title="Ulster County">
          Ulster
         </a>
         and
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dutchess_County" title="Dutchess County">
          Dutchess
         </a>
         counties in New York.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Interstates">
        Interstates
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York_metropolitan_area&amp;action=edit&amp;section=36" title="Edit section: Interstates">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:I-495_(NY)_4.JPG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1704" data-file-width="2272" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/I-495_%28NY%29_4.JPG/220px-I-495_%28NY%29_4.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/I-495_%28NY%29_4.JPG/330px-I-495_%28NY%29_4.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/I-495_%28NY%29_4.JPG/440px-I-495_%28NY%29_4.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:I-495_(NY)_4.JPG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Long_Island_Expressway" title="Long Island Expressway">
          Long Island Expressway (I-495)
         </a>
         , viewing eastbound in
         <a href="/wiki/Corona,_Queens" title="Corona, Queens">
          Corona, Queens
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>

       <li>
        <img alt="" data-file-height="601" data-file-width="751" height="20" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/I-476.svg/25px-I-476.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/I-476.svg/38px-I-476.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/I-476.svg/50px-I-476.svg.png 2x" width="25"/>

        <img alt="" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="600" height="20" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/PA-33.svg/20px-PA-33.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/PA-33.svg/30px-PA-33.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/PA-33.svg/40px-PA-33.svg.png 2x" width="20"/>

      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Other_limited-access_roads">
        Other limited-access roads
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York_metropolitan_area&amp;action=edit&amp;section=39" title="Edit section: Other limited-access roads">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Parkway_Congestion_02.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1600" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Parkway_Congestion_02.jpg/220px-Parkway_Congestion_02.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Parkway_Congestion_02.jpg/330px-Parkway_Congestion_02.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Parkway_Congestion_02.jpg/440px-Parkway_Congestion_02.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Parkway_Congestion_02.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Heavy traffic on the
         <a href="/wiki/Garden_State_Parkway" title="Garden State Parkway">
          Garden State Parkway
         </a>
         in
         <a href="/wiki/Wall_Township,_New_Jersey" title="Wall Township, New Jersey">
          Wall Township
         </a>
         , Monmouth County, New Jersey.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Some of these roads have a numerical designation assigned to it:
      </p>

        </span>
       </li>
