       <span class="mw-headline" id="Named_bridges_and_tunnels">
        Named bridges and tunnels
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York_metropolitan_area&amp;action=edit&amp;section=40" title="Edit section: Named bridges and tunnels">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="mw-stack mobile-float-reset" style="box-sizing: border-box; float:right;">
       <div style="overflow: hidden; margin: 1px;">
        <div class="thumb tright">
         <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Brooklyn_Bridge_NYC_August_16,_2010.JPG">
           <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2304" data-file-width="3072" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Brooklyn_Bridge_NYC_August_16%2C_2010.JPG/220px-Brooklyn_Bridge_NYC_August_16%2C_2010.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Brooklyn_Bridge_NYC_August_16%2C_2010.JPG/330px-Brooklyn_Bridge_NYC_August_16%2C_2010.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Brooklyn_Bridge_NYC_August_16%2C_2010.JPG/440px-Brooklyn_Bridge_NYC_August_16%2C_2010.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
          </a>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <div class="magnify">
            <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Brooklyn_Bridge_NYC_August_16,_2010.JPG" title="Enlarge">
            </a>
           </div>
           The
           <a href="/wiki/Brooklyn_Bridge" title="Brooklyn Bridge">
            Brooklyn Bridge
           </a>
           .
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="thumb tright">
         <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Verrazano.jpg">
           <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="533" data-file-width="800" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Verrazano.jpg/220px-Verrazano.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Verrazano.jpg/330px-Verrazano.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Verrazano.jpg/440px-Verrazano.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
          </a>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <div class="magnify">
            <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Verrazano.jpg" title="Enlarge">
            </a>
           </div>
           The
           <a href="/wiki/Verrazano-Narrows_Bridge" title="Verrazano-Narrows Bridge">
            Verrazano-Narrows Bridge
           </a>
           , one of the world's longest
           <a href="/wiki/Suspension_bridge" title="Suspension bridge">
            suspension bridges
           </a>
           ,
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-infoplease.com_224-0">
            <a href="#cite_note-infoplease.com-224">
             [220]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Verrazano-Narrows_Bridge_225-0">
            <a href="#cite_note-Verrazano-Narrows_Bridge-225">
             [221]
            </a>
           </sup>
           connects
           <a href="/wiki/Brooklyn" title="Brooklyn">
            Brooklyn
           </a>
           and
           <a href="/wiki/Staten_Island" title="Staten Island">
            Staten Island
           </a>
           across
           <a href="/wiki/The_Narrows" title="The Narrows">
            The Narrows
           </a>
           .
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="thumb tright">
         <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:GreatSouth-B-B.jpg">
           <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1500" data-file-width="2000" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/GreatSouth-B-B.jpg/220px-GreatSouth-B-B.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/GreatSouth-B-B.jpg/330px-GreatSouth-B-B.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/GreatSouth-B-B.jpg/440px-GreatSouth-B-B.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
          </a>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <div class="magnify">
            <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:GreatSouth-B-B.jpg" title="Enlarge">
            </a>
           </div>
           The
           <a href="/wiki/Great_South_Bay_Bridge" title="Great South Bay Bridge">
            Great South Bay Bridge
           </a>
           , in Suffolk County, connects the mainland of Long Island to
           <a href="/wiki/Barrier_island" title="Barrier island">
            barrier islands
           </a>
           across the
           <a href="/wiki/Great_South_Bay" title="Great South Bay">
            Great South Bay
           </a>
           .
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Albertus_L._Meyers_Bridge" title="Albertus L. Meyers Bridge">
         Albertus L. Meyers Bridge
        </a>
        , Allentown, PA, carrying Eighth Street over the
        <a href="/wiki/Little_Lehigh_Creek" title="Little Lehigh Creek">
         Little Lehigh Creek
        </a>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Hamilton_Bridge" title="Alexander Hamilton Bridge">
         Alexander Hamilton Bridge
        </a>
        connecting the Trans-Manhattan Expressway in the Washington Heights section of Manhattan and the Cross-Bronx Expressway, as part of Interstate 95
       </li>
       <li>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Basilone_Bridge" title="Basilone Bridge">
         Basilone Bridge
        </a>
        (part of I-95 and the New Jersey Turnpike)
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Bayonne_Bridge" title="Bayonne Bridge">
         Bayonne Bridge
        </a>
        (part of NY 440 and NJ 440), scheduled to undergo a $1 billion project to raise the roadway by 64 feet to 215 feet to allow taller
        <a href="/wiki/Container_ship" title="Container ship">
         container ships
        </a>
        to pass underneath to access
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Seaport" title="Seaport">
         seaports
        </a>
        in New York City and northern New Jersey.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-226">
         <a href="#cite_note-226">
          [222]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Bear_Mountain_Bridge" title="Bear Mountain Bridge">
         Bear Mountain Bridge
        </a>
        (part of US 6 and US 202)
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Bronx%E2%80%93Whitestone_Bridge" title="Bronx–Whitestone Bridge">
         Bronx–Whitestone Bridge
        </a>
        (part of I-678) – connects the boroughs of Bronx and Queens.
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Brooklyn_Bridge" title="Brooklyn Bridge">
         Brooklyn Bridge
        </a>
        , iconic of New York City and designated a
        <a href="/wiki/National_Historic_Landmark" title="National Historic Landmark">
         National Historic Landmark
        </a>
        by the
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U.S._National_Park_Service" title="U.S. National Park Service">
         U.S. National Park Service
        </a>
        on January 29, 1964.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-227">
         <a href="#cite_note-227">
          [223]
         </a>
        </sup>
        Connects Brooklyn and lower Manhattan (at Park Row and City Hall).
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Brooklyn%E2%80%93Battery_Tunnel" title="Brooklyn–Battery Tunnel">
         Brooklyn–Battery Tunnel
        </a>
        (part of I-478), officially renamed the Hugh L. Carey Tunnel, in honor of the former New York State governor – connects Brooklyn and lower Manhattan (financial district).
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Delaware_Water_Gap_Toll_Bridge" title="Delaware Water Gap Toll Bridge">
         Delaware Water Gap Toll Bridge
        </a>
        (part of I-80 crossing the
        <a href="/wiki/Delaware_River" title="Delaware River">
         Delaware River
        </a>
        )
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Driscoll_Bridge" title="Driscoll Bridge">
         Driscoll Bridge
        </a>
        (part of the Garden State Parkway), with a total of 15 travel lanes and 6 shoulder lanes, the widest motor vehicle bridge in the world by number of lanes
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TOLLROADSnews,_Peter_Samuel_228-0">
         <a href="#cite_note-TOLLROADSnews,_Peter_Samuel-228">
          [224]
         </a>
        </sup>
        and one of the world's busiest.
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Easton%E2%80%93Phillipsburg_Toll_Bridge" title="Easton–Phillipsburg Toll Bridge">
         Easton–Phillipsburg Toll Bridge
        </a>
        (part of US 22 crossing the
        <a href="/wiki/Delaware_River" title="Delaware River">
         Delaware River
        </a>
        )
       </li>
       <li>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ed_Koch_Queensboro_Bridge" title="Ed Koch Queensboro Bridge">
         Ed Koch Queensboro Bridge
        </a>
        (part of NY 25) – renamed in honor of former New York City Mayor Edward I. Koch, also known informally as the "59th Street Bridge". Connects Queens and east side of Manhattan.
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/George_Washington_Bridge" title="George Washington Bridge">
         George Washington Bridge
        </a>
        (part of I-95 and US 1-9/46), the world's busiest motor vehicle bridge
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-panynj.gov_221-1">
         <a href="#cite_note-panynj.gov-221">
          [217]
         </a>
        </sup>
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-abcgwb_222-1">
         <a href="#cite_note-abcgwb-222">
          [218]
         </a>
        </sup>
        and one of the world's widest, with 14 lanes.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TOLLROADSnews,_Peter_Samuel_228-1">
         <a href="#cite_note-TOLLROADSnews,_Peter_Samuel-228">
          [224]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Goethals_Bridge" title="Goethals Bridge">
         Goethals Bridge
        </a>
        (part of I-278)
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Great_South_Bay_Bridge" title="Great South Bay Bridge">
         Great South Bay Bridge
        </a>
        , Long Island
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Hill_to_Hill_Bridge" title="Hill to Hill Bridge">
         Hill to Hill Bridge
        </a>
        , part of
        <a href="/wiki/Pennsylvania_Route_378" title="Pennsylvania Route 378">
         PA-378
        </a>
        over the
        <a href="/wiki/Lehigh_River" title="Lehigh River">
         Lehigh River
        </a>
        in
        <a href="/wiki/Bethlehem,_Pennsylvania" title="Bethlehem, Pennsylvania">
         Bethlehem, Pennsylvania
        </a>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Heroes_Tunnel" title="Heroes Tunnel">
         Heroes Tunnel
        </a>
        (formerly the West Rock Tunnel) (part of CT 15)
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Holland_Tunnel" title="Holland Tunnel">
         Holland Tunnel
        </a>
        (part of I-78)
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Interstate_78_Toll_Bridge" title="Interstate 78 Toll Bridge">
         Interstate 78 Toll Bridge
        </a>
        (over the
        <a href="/wiki/Delaware_River" title="Delaware River">
         Delaware River
        </a>
        )
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Lehigh_Tunnel" title="Lehigh Tunnel">
         Lehigh Tunnel
        </a>
        (part of
        <a href="/wiki/Interstate_476" title="Interstate 476">
         Interstate 476
        </a>
        ) in Carbon and Lehigh Counties, PA
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Lincoln_Tunnel" title="Lincoln Tunnel">
         Lincoln Tunnel
        </a>
        (part of Route 495)
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Manhattan_Bridge" title="Manhattan Bridge">
         Manhattan Bridge
        </a>
        , connecting Brooklyn to
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Manhattan%27s_Chinatown" title="Manhattan's Chinatown">
         Manhattan's Chinatown
        </a>
        , carries 4 tracks of the
        <span class="nowrap">
         <a href="/wiki/B_(New_York_City_Subway_service)" title="B (New York City Subway service)">
          B
         </a>
        </span>
        , ​
        <span class="nowrap">
         <a href="/wiki/D_(New_York_City_Subway_service)" title="D (New York City Subway service)">
          D
         </a>
        </span>
        ​,
        <span class="nowrap">
         <a href="/wiki/N_(New_York_City_Subway_service)" title="N (New York City Subway service)">
          N
         </a>
        </span>
        , and ​
        <span class="nowrap">
         <a href="/wiki/Q_(New_York_City_Subway_service)" title="Q (New York City Subway service)">
          Q
         </a>
        </span>
        trains of the New York City Subway, in addition to other traffic.
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Mid-Hudson_Bridge" title="Mid-Hudson Bridge">
         Mid-Hudson Bridge
        </a>
        (part of US 44 and NY 55)
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Minsi_Trail_Bridge" title="Minsi Trail Bridge">
         Minsi Trail Bridge
        </a>
        , Bethlehem, PA, carrying Stefko Boulevard over the
        <a href="/wiki/Lehigh_River" title="Lehigh River">
         Lehigh River
        </a>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Newark_Bay_Bridge" title="Newark Bay Bridge">
         Newark Bay Bridge
        </a>
        (part of I-78)
       </li>
       <li>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_Hope_%E2%80%93_Lambertville_Toll_Bridge" title="New Hope – Lambertville Toll Bridge">
         New Hope – Lambertville Toll Bridge
        </a>
        (part of US 202 crossing the
        <a href="/wiki/Delaware_River" title="Delaware River">
         Delaware River
        </a>
        )
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Newburgh%E2%80%93Beacon_Bridge" title="Newburgh–Beacon Bridge">
         Newburgh–Beacon Bridge
        </a>
        (part of I-84 and NY 52)
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Otisville_Tunnel" title="Otisville Tunnel">
         Otisville Tunnel
        </a>
        (takes the
        <a href="/wiki/Metro-North_Railroad" title="Metro-North Railroad">
         Metro-North Railroad
        </a>
        <a href="/wiki/Port_Jervis_Line" title="Port Jervis Line">
         Port Jervis Line
        </a>
        through the
        <a href="/wiki/Shawangunk_Ridge" title="Shawangunk Ridge">
         Shawangunk Ridge
        </a>
        in
        <a href="/wiki/Orange_County,_New_York" title="Orange County, New York">
         Orange County, New York
        </a>
        )
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Outerbridge_Crossing" title="Outerbridge Crossing">
         Outerbridge Crossing
        </a>
        (part of NY 440 and NJ 440)
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Pearl_Harbor_Memorial_Bridge_(Connecticut)" title="Pearl Harbor Memorial Bridge (Connecticut)">
         Pearl Harbor Memorial Bridge
        </a>
        (part of I-95 and the Connecticut Turnpike)
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Philip_J._Fahy_Memorial_Bridge" title="Philip J. Fahy Memorial Bridge">
         Philip J. Fahy Memorial Bridge
        </a>
        , Bethlehem, PA, carrying New Street over the
        <a href="/wiki/Lehigh_River" title="Lehigh River">
         Lehigh River
        </a>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Poughkeepsie_Bridge" title="Poughkeepsie Bridge">
         Poughkeepsie Bridge
        </a>
        , also known as Walkway over the Hudson, the world's longest
        <a href="/wiki/Pedestrian" title="Pedestrian">
         pedestrian
        </a>
        bridge,
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-guinnessworldrecords.com_223-1">
         <a href="#cite_note-guinnessworldrecords.com-223">
          [219]
         </a>
        </sup>
        connecting
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ulster_County" title="Ulster County">
         Ulster
        </a>
        and
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dutchess_County" title="Dutchess County">
         Dutchess
        </a>
        counties in New York
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Pulaski_Skyway" title="Pulaski Skyway">
         Pulaski Skyway
        </a>
        (part of US 1–9)
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Queens%E2%80%93Midtown_Tunnel" title="Queens–Midtown Tunnel">
         Queens–Midtown Tunnel
        </a>
        (part of I-495) – connects Queens and Midtown Manhattan.
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Scudder_Falls_Bridge" title="Scudder Falls Bridge">
         Scudder Falls Bridge
        </a>
        (part of I-95 crossing the
        <a href="/wiki/Delaware_River" title="Delaware River">
         Delaware River
        </a>
        )
       </li>
       <li>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sikorsky_Memorial_Bridge" title="Sikorsky Memorial Bridge">
         Sikorsky Memorial Bridge
        </a>
        (part of CT 15 Merritt &amp; Wilbur Cross Parkways)
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Tappan_Zee_Bridge_(2017%E2%80%93present)" title="Tappan Zee Bridge (2017–present)">
         Tappan Zee Bridge
        </a>
        (part of I-87, I-287, and the New York State Thruway), the longest bridge in New York State; planned to undergo a $4 billion replacement.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-229">
         <a href="#cite_note-229">
          [225]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Edison_Bridge_(New_Jersey)" title="Edison Bridge (New Jersey)">
         Thomas Alva Edison Memorial Bridge
        </a>
        (part of US 9)
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Throgs_Neck_Bridge" title="Throgs Neck Bridge">
         Throgs Neck Bridge
        </a>
        (part of I-295) – connects the boroughs of Bronx and Queens (at western end of Long Island Sound).
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Trenton%E2%80%93Morrisville_Toll_Bridge" title="Trenton–Morrisville Toll Bridge">
         Trenton–Morrisville Toll Bridge
        </a>
        (part of US 1)
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Triborough_Bridge" title="Triborough Bridge">
         Triborough Bridge
        </a>
        (part of I-278), officially renamed the Robert F. Kennedy (RFK) Bridge, also known as the RFK–Triboro Bridge – connects the three boroughs of Manhattan, Bronx and Queens (hence its name).
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Verrazano-Narrows_Bridge" title="Verrazano-Narrows Bridge">
         Verrazano-Narrows Bridge
        </a>
        (part of I-278), the longest
        <a href="/wiki/Suspension_bridge" title="Suspension bridge">
         suspension bridge
        </a>
        in the
        <a href="/wiki/Americas" title="Americas">
         Americas
        </a>
        and one of the longest in the world – connects the boroughs of Staten Island and Brooklyn.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-infoplease.com_224-1">
         <a href="#cite_note-infoplease.com-224">
          [220]
         </a>
        </sup>
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Verrazano-Narrows_Bridge_225-1">
         <a href="#cite_note-Verrazano-Narrows_Bridge-225">
          [221]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/William_A._Stickel_Memorial_Bridge" title="William A. Stickel Memorial Bridge">
         William A. Stickel Memorial Bridge
        </a>
        (part of I-280)
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Williamsburg_Bridge" title="Williamsburg Bridge">
         Williamsburg Bridge
        </a>
        , carries 2 tracks of the
        <span class="nowrap">
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/J_(New_York_City_Subway_service)" title="J (New York City Subway service)">
          J
         </a>
        </span>
        ,
        <span class="nowrap">
         <a href="/wiki/M_(New_York_City_Subway_service)" title="M (New York City Subway service)">
          M
         </a>
        </span>
        , and
        <span class="nowrap">
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Z_(New_York_City_Subway_service)" title="Z (New York City Subway service)">
          Z
         </a>
        </span>
        ​ trains of the New York City Subway, in addition to other traffic – connects the boroughs of Brooklyn and Manhattan (lower east side).
       </li>
      </ul>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Commuter_bus">
        Commuter bus
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York_metropolitan_area&amp;action=edit&amp;section=41" title="Edit section: Commuter bus">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_Jersey_Transit" title="New Jersey Transit">
        New Jersey Transit
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Academy_Bus" title="Academy Bus">
        Academy Bus
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Coach_USA" title="Coach USA">
        Coach USA
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Transportation" title="Spanish Transportation">
        Spanish Transportation
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Trailways_of_New_York" title="Trailways of New York">
        Trailways of New York
       </a>
       , and several other companies operate commuter coaches into the
       <a href="/wiki/Port_Authority_Bus_Terminal" title="Port Authority Bus Terminal">
        Port Authority Bus Terminal
       </a>
       in Manhattan, and many other bus services in New Jersey. Bus services also operate in other nearby counties in the states of New York and Connecticut, but most terminate at a subway terminal or other rail station.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Major_airports">
        Major airports
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York_metropolitan_area&amp;action=edit&amp;section=42" title="Edit section: Major airports">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Aviation_in_the_New_York_metropolitan_area" title="Aviation in the New York metropolitan area">
        Aviation in the New York metropolitan area
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:JFK_airtrain.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1784" data-file-width="1443" height="272" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/JFK_airtrain.jpg/220px-JFK_airtrain.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/JFK_airtrain.jpg/330px-JFK_airtrain.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/JFK_airtrain.jpg/440px-JFK_airtrain.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:JFK_airtrain.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/AirTrain_(JFK)" title="AirTrain (JFK)">
          AirTrain
         </a>
         at
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/JFK_International_Airport" title="JFK International Airport">
          JFK International Airport
         </a>
         in
         <a href="/wiki/Jamaica,_Queens" title="Jamaica, Queens">
          Jamaica, Queens
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The three busiest airports in the New York metropolitan area include
       <a href="/wiki/John_F._Kennedy_International_Airport" title="John F. Kennedy International Airport">
        John F. Kennedy International Airport
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Newark_Liberty_International_Airport" title="Newark Liberty International Airport">
        Newark Liberty International Airport
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/LaGuardia_Airport" title="LaGuardia Airport">
        LaGuardia Airport
       </a>
       ; 130.5 million travelers used these three airports in 2016, and the metropolitan area's airspace is the busiest in the nation.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYMetroAirspace_10-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-NYMetroAirspace-10">
         [10]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <table class="wikitable">
       <tr>
        <th valign="bottom">
         Airport
        </th>
        <th valign="bottom">
         <a href="/wiki/IATA_airport_code" title="IATA airport code">
          IATA code
         </a>
        </th>
        <th valign="bottom">
         <a href="/wiki/ICAO_airport_code" title="ICAO airport code">
          ICAO code
         </a>
        </th>
        <th valign="bottom">
         <a href="/wiki/County_(United_States)" title="County (United States)">
          County
         </a>
        </th>
        <th valign="bottom">
         State
        </th>
       </tr>

       The following smaller airports are also in the metro area and provide daily commercial service:

      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Commuter_usage">
        Commuter usage
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York_metropolitan_area&amp;action=edit&amp;section=43" title="Edit section: Commuter usage">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       According to the 2010 American Community Survey, 54.3% (5,476,169) of commuters used a car or other private vehicle alone, 7.0% (708,788) used a carpool, 27.0% (2,721,372) used public transportation, 5.5% (558,434) walked to work, 2.0% (200,448) used some other means of transportation such as a bicycle to get to work.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-230">
        <a href="#cite_note-230">
         [226]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Culture_and_contemporary_life">
        Culture and contemporary life
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York_metropolitan_area&amp;action=edit&amp;section=44" title="Edit section: Culture and contemporary life">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="mw-stack mobile-float-reset" style="box-sizing: border-box; float:right;">
       <div style="overflow: hidden; margin: 1px;">
        <div class="thumb tright">
         <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Metropolitan_museum_of_art_2.jpg">
           <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2805" data-file-width="3393" height="182" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Metropolitan_museum_of_art_2.jpg/220px-Metropolitan_museum_of_art_2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Metropolitan_museum_of_art_2.jpg/330px-Metropolitan_museum_of_art_2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Metropolitan_museum_of_art_2.jpg/440px-Metropolitan_museum_of_art_2.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
          </a>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <div class="magnify">
            <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Metropolitan_museum_of_art_2.jpg" title="Enlarge">
            </a>
           </div>
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Metropolitan_Museum_of_Art" title="The Metropolitan Museum of Art">
            The Metropolitan Museum of Art
           </a>
           , part of
           <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Museum_Mile,_New_York_City" title="Museum Mile, New York City">
            Museum Mile
           </a>
           in the
           <a href="/wiki/Carnegie_Hill" title="Carnegie Hill">
            Carnegie Hill
           </a>
           neighborhood of Manhattan's
           <a href="/wiki/Upper_East_Side" title="Upper East Side">
            Upper East Side
           </a>
           , is one of the largest museums in the world.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231">
            <a href="#cite_note-231">
             [227]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="thumb tright">
         <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Citi_Field_2011.JPG">
           <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2647" data-file-width="3529" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Citi_Field_2011.JPG/220px-Citi_Field_2011.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Citi_Field_2011.JPG/330px-Citi_Field_2011.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Citi_Field_2011.JPG/440px-Citi_Field_2011.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
          </a>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <div class="magnify">
            <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Citi_Field_2011.JPG" title="Enlarge">
            </a>
           </div>
           <a href="/wiki/Citi_Field" title="Citi Field">
            Citi Field
           </a>
           in
           <a href="/wiki/Flushing,_Queens" title="Flushing, Queens">
            Flushing, Queens
           </a>
           is the home of the
           <a href="/wiki/New_York_Mets" title="New York Mets">
            New York Mets
           </a>
           .
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="thumb tright">
         <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Yankee_Stadium_upper_deck_2010.jpg">
           <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1616" data-file-width="2154" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/Yankee_Stadium_upper_deck_2010.jpg/220px-Yankee_Stadium_upper_deck_2010.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/Yankee_Stadium_upper_deck_2010.jpg/330px-Yankee_Stadium_upper_deck_2010.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/Yankee_Stadium_upper_deck_2010.jpg/440px-Yankee_Stadium_upper_deck_2010.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
          </a>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <div class="magnify">
            <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Yankee_Stadium_upper_deck_2010.jpg" title="Enlarge">
            </a>
           </div>
           <a href="/wiki/Yankee_Stadium" title="Yankee Stadium">
            Yankee Stadium
           </a>
           in the
           <a href="/wiki/South_Bronx" title="South Bronx">
            South Bronx
           </a>
           is the home of the
           <a href="/wiki/New_York_Yankees" title="New York Yankees">
            New York Yankees
           </a>
           .
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="thumb tright">
         <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:New_Meadowlands_Stadium_Mezz_Corner.jpg">
           <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2586" data-file-width="3892" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/New_Meadowlands_Stadium_Mezz_Corner.jpg/220px-New_Meadowlands_Stadium_Mezz_Corner.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/New_Meadowlands_Stadium_Mezz_Corner.jpg/330px-New_Meadowlands_Stadium_Mezz_Corner.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/New_Meadowlands_Stadium_Mezz_Corner.jpg/440px-New_Meadowlands_Stadium_Mezz_Corner.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
          </a>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <div class="magnify">
            <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:New_Meadowlands_Stadium_Mezz_Corner.jpg" title="Enlarge">
            </a>
           </div>
           <a href="/wiki/MetLife_Stadium" title="MetLife Stadium">
            MetLife Stadium
           </a>
           , in
           <a href="/wiki/East_Rutherford,_New_Jersey" title="East Rutherford, New Jersey">
            East Rutherford, New Jersey
           </a>
           , home to the
           <a href="/wiki/New_York_Giants" title="New York Giants">
            New York Giants
           </a>
           and
           <a href="/wiki/New_York_Jets" title="New York Jets">
            New York Jets
           </a>
           , is the most expensive stadium ever built,
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Esteban_232-0">
            <a href="#cite_note-Esteban-232">
             [228]
            </a>
           </sup>
           at approximately $1.6 billion.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-233">
            <a href="#cite_note-233">
             [229]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="thumb tright">
         <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Britney_Spears_MSG.jpg">
           <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1536" data-file-width="2048" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Britney_Spears_MSG.jpg/220px-Britney_Spears_MSG.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Britney_Spears_MSG.jpg/330px-Britney_Spears_MSG.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Britney_Spears_MSG.jpg/440px-Britney_Spears_MSG.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
          </a>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <div class="magnify">
            <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Britney_Spears_MSG.jpg" title="Enlarge">
            </a>
           </div>
           The
           <a href="/wiki/New_York_Knicks" title="New York Knicks">
            New York Knicks
           </a>
           ,
           <a href="/wiki/New_York_Rangers" title="New York Rangers">
            Rangers
           </a>
           , and
           <a href="/wiki/New_York_Liberty" title="New York Liberty">
            Liberty
           </a>
           sports teams play at
           <a href="/wiki/Madison_Square_Garden" title="Madison Square Garden">
            Madison Square Garden
           </a>
           in Midtown Manhattan.
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="thumb tright">
         <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Tsq_green_chairs_jeh.jpg">
           <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2770" data-file-width="3054" height="200" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Tsq_green_chairs_jeh.jpg/220px-Tsq_green_chairs_jeh.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Tsq_green_chairs_jeh.jpg/330px-Tsq_green_chairs_jeh.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Tsq_green_chairs_jeh.jpg/440px-Tsq_green_chairs_jeh.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
          </a>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <div class="magnify">
            <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Tsq_green_chairs_jeh.jpg" title="Enlarge">
            </a>
           </div>
           According to
           <i>
            <a href="/wiki/Travel_%2B_Leisure" title="Travel + Leisure">
             Travel + Leisure
            </a>
           </i>
           magazine's October 2011 survey,
           <a href="/wiki/Times_Square" title="Times Square">
            Times Square
           </a>
           in Midtown Manhattan, iconified as the "Crossroads of the World",
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-234">
            <a href="#cite_note-234">
             [230]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-235">
            <a href="#cite_note-235">
             [231]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-236">
            <a href="#cite_note-236">
             [232]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-237">
            <a href="#cite_note-237">
             [233]
            </a>
           </sup>
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-238">
            <a href="#cite_note-238">
             [234]
            </a>
           </sup>
           is the world's most visited tourist attraction, bringing in over 39 million visitors annually.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-239">
            <a href="#cite_note-239">
             [235]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/New_York_City#Culture_and_contemporary_life" title="New York City">
        New York City § Culture and contemporary life
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       New York City has been described as the cultural capital of the world by the
       <a href="/wiki/Consul_(representative)" title="Consul (representative)">
        diplomatic consulates
       </a>
       of
       <a href="/wiki/Iceland" title="Iceland">
        Iceland
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-240">
        <a href="#cite_note-240">
         [236]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Latvia" title="Latvia">
        Latvia
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-241">
        <a href="#cite_note-241">
         [237]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and by New York's own
       <a href="/wiki/Baruch_College" title="Baruch College">
        Baruch College
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-242">
        <a href="#cite_note-242">
         [238]
        </a>
       </sup>
       A book containing a series of essays titled
       <i>
        New York, culture capital of the world, 1940–1965
       </i>
       has also been published as showcased by the
       <a href="/wiki/National_Library_of_Australia" title="National Library of Australia">
        National Library of Australia
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-243">
        <a href="#cite_note-243">
         [239]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Tom_Wolfe" title="Tom Wolfe">
        Tom Wolfe
       </a>
       has quoted regarding New York's culture that "Culture just seems to be in the air, like part of the weather."
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-244">
        <a href="#cite_note-244">
         [240]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Although Manhattan remains the epicenter of cultural life in the metropolitan area, the entire region is replete with prominent cultural institutions, with artistic performances and ethnically oriented events receiving international attention throughout the year.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Sports_teams">
        Sports teams
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York_metropolitan_area&amp;action=edit&amp;section=45" title="Edit section: Sports teams">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Further information:
       <a href="/wiki/Sports_in_New_York_City" title="Sports in New York City">
        Sports in New York City
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       New York City is home to the
       <a href="/wiki/Headquarters" title="Headquarters">
        headquarters
       </a>
       of the
       <a href="/wiki/National_Football_League" title="National Football League">
        National Football League
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-245">
        <a href="#cite_note-245">
         [241]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Major_League_Baseball" title="Major League Baseball">
        Major League Baseball
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-246">
        <a href="#cite_note-246">
         [242]
        </a>
       </sup>
       the
       <a href="/wiki/National_Basketball_Association" title="National Basketball Association">
        National Basketball Association
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-247">
        <a href="#cite_note-247">
         [243]
        </a>
       </sup>
       the
       <a href="/wiki/National_Hockey_League" title="National Hockey League">
        National Hockey League
       </a>
       ,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-248">
        <a href="#cite_note-248">
         [244]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Major_League_Soccer" title="Major League Soccer">
        Major League Soccer
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-249">
        <a href="#cite_note-249">
         [245]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Four of the ten most expensive
       <a href="/wiki/Stadium" title="Stadium">
        stadiums
       </a>
       ever built worldwide (
       <a href="/wiki/MetLife_Stadium" title="MetLife Stadium">
        MetLife Stadium
       </a>
       , the new
       <a href="/wiki/Yankee_Stadium" title="Yankee Stadium">
        Yankee Stadium
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Madison_Square_Garden" title="Madison Square Garden">
        Madison Square Garden
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Citi_Field" title="Citi Field">
        Citi Field
       </a>
       ) are located in the New York metropolitan area.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Esteban_232-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Esteban-232">
         [228]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The New York metropolitan area has the
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_American_and_Canadian_cities_by_number_of_major_professional_sports_franchises" title="List of American and Canadian cities by number of major professional sports franchises">
        highest total number of professional sports teams
       </a>
       in these five leagues.
      </p>
      <p>
       Listing of the professional sports teams in the New York metropolitan area:
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/National_Basketball_Association" title="National Basketball Association">
         National Basketball Association
        </a>
        (NBA)
        <ul>
         <li>
          <a href="/wiki/Brooklyn_Nets" title="Brooklyn Nets">
           Brooklyn Nets
          </a>
          (
          <a href="/wiki/Brooklyn" title="Brooklyn">
           Brooklyn
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="/wiki/New_York_City" title="New York City">
           New York City
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="/wiki/New_York_(state)" title="New York (state)">
           NY
          </a>
          )
         </li>
         <li>
          <a href="/wiki/New_York_Knicks" title="New York Knicks">
           New York Knicks
          </a>
          (
          <a href="/wiki/Manhattan" title="Manhattan">
           Manhattan
          </a>
          , New York City, NY)
         </li>
        </ul>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Women%27s_National_Basketball_Association" title="Women's National Basketball Association">
         Women's National Basketball Association
        </a>
        (WNBA)
        <ul>
         <li>
          <a href="/wiki/New_York_Liberty" title="New York Liberty">
           New York Liberty
          </a>
          (Manhattan, New York City, NY)
         </li>
        </ul>
       </li>
       <li>
        <a href="/wiki/Major_League_Baseball" title="Major League Baseball">
         Major League Baseball
        </a>
        (MLB)
        <ul>
         <li>
          <a href="/wiki/New_York_Mets" title="New York Mets">

          </a>
          (
          <a href="/wiki/Queens" title="Queens">
           Queens
          </a>
          , New York City, NY)
         </li>

          </a>

          <a href="/wiki/The_Bronx" title="The Bronx">

          </a>

        </ul>
       </li>

      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Media">
        Media
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York_metropolitan_area&amp;action=edit&amp;section=46" title="Edit section: Media">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Media_in_New_York_City" title="Media in New York City">
        Media in New York City
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       The New York City metropolitan area is home to the headquarters of several well-known media companies, subsidiaries, and publications, including
       <a href="/wiki/Thomson_Reuters" title="Thomson Reuters">
        Thomson Reuters
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times_Company" title="The New York Times Company">
        The New York Times Company
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Associated_Press" title="Associated Press">
        Associated Press
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Time_Warner" title="Time Warner">
        Time Warner
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/NBCUniversal" title="NBCUniversal">
        NBCUniversal
       </a>
       , the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hearst_Corporation" title="Hearst Corporation">
        Hearst Corporation
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Viacom" title="Viacom">
        Viacom
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/News_Corporation" title="News Corporation">
        News Corporation
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/The_Wall_Street_Journal" title="The Wall Street Journal">
        The Wall Street Journal
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Fox_News" title="Fox News">
        Fox News
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/American_Broadcasting_Company" title="American Broadcasting Company">
        ABC
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/CBS" title="CBS">
        CBS
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/NBC" title="NBC">
        NBC
       </a>
       . Local television channels include
       <a href="/wiki/WCBS-TV" title="WCBS-TV">
        WCBS-TV
       </a>
       2 (CBS),
       <a href="/wiki/WNBC" title="WNBC">
        WNBC
       </a>
       4 (NBC),
       <a href="/wiki/WNYW" title="WNYW">
        WNYW
       </a>
       5 (FOX),
       <a href="/wiki/WABC-TV" title="WABC-TV">
        WABC-TV
       </a>
       7 (ABC),
       <a href="/wiki/WWOR-TV" title="WWOR-TV">
        WWOR-TV
       </a>
       9 (MyNetworkTV),
       <a href="/wiki/WPIX" title="WPIX">
        WPIX
       </a>
       11 (CW),
       <a href="/wiki/WNET" title="WNET">
        WNET
       </a>
       13 (PBS),
       <a href="/wiki/WNYE-TV" title="WNYE-TV">
        WNYE-TV
       </a>
       25 (NYC Media) and
       <a href="/wiki/WPXN-TV" title="WPXN-TV">
        WPXN-TV
       </a>
       31 (
       <a href="/wiki/Ion_Television" title="Ion Television">
        Ion
       </a>
       ).
       <a href="/wiki/NY1" title="NY1">
        NY1
       </a>
       is a 24/7 local news provider available only to
       <a href="/wiki/Cable_television" title="Cable television">
        cable television
       </a>
       subscribers. Radio stations serving the area include:
       <a href="/wiki/WNYC" title="WNYC">
        WNYC
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/WKCR" title="WKCR">
        WKCR
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/WFMU" title="WFMU">
        WFMU
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/WABC-AM" title="WABC-AM">
        WABC-AM
       </a>
       , and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/WFAN" title="WFAN">
        WFAN
       </a>
       . Many television and radio stations use the top of the
       <a href="/wiki/Empire_State_Building" title="Empire State Building">
        Empire State Building
       </a>
       to broadcast their
       <a href="/wiki/Terrestrial_television" title="Terrestrial television">
        terrestrial television
       </a>
       signals, while some media entities broadcast from studios in
       <a href="/wiki/Times_Square" title="Times Square">
        Times Square
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       The New York metropolitan area is extensive enough so that its own channels must compete with channels from neighboring television markets (including Philadelphia,
       <a href="/wiki/Wyoming_Valley" title="Wyoming Valley">
        Scranton/Wilkes-Barre
       </a>
       , and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hartford" title="Hartford">
        Hartford
       </a>
       ) within its outlying counties. Cable companies offer such competition in the Pennsylvania portion, Connecticut, and a few counties in central New Jersey.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Theme_parks">
        Theme parks
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York_metropolitan_area&amp;action=edit&amp;section=47" title="Edit section: Theme parks">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="In_New_Jersey">
        In New Jersey
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York_metropolitan_area&amp;action=edit&amp;section=48" title="Edit section: In New Jersey">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="center">
       <div class="thumb tnone">
        <div class="thumbinner" style="width:802px;">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:SFGadv_Skyline.jpg">
          <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="989" data-file-width="6392" height="124" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/SFGadv_Skyline.jpg/800px-SFGadv_Skyline.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/SFGadv_Skyline.jpg/1200px-SFGadv_Skyline.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/SFGadv_Skyline.jpg/1600px-SFGadv_Skyline.jpg 2x" width="800"/>
         </a>
         <div class="thumbcaption">
          <div class="magnify">
           <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:SFGadv_Skyline.jpg" title="Enlarge">
           </a>
          </div>
          Skyline of
          <a href="/wiki/Six_Flags_Great_Adventure" title="Six Flags Great Adventure">
           Six Flags Great Adventure
          </a>
          in
          <a href="/wiki/Jackson_Township,_New_Jersey" title="Jackson Township, New Jersey">
           Jackson Township
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="/wiki/Ocean_County,_New_Jersey" title="Ocean County, New Jersey">
           Ocean County, New Jersey
          </a>
          , the world's largest
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Theme_park" title="Theme park">
           theme park
          </a>
          in 2013.
          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-250">
           <a href="#cite_note-250">
            [246]
           </a>
          </sup>
          To the far left is
          <a href="/wiki/Kingda_Ka" title="Kingda Ka">
           Kingda Ka
          </a>
          , the world's tallest
          <a href="/wiki/Roller_coaster" title="Roller coaster">
           roller coaster
          </a>
          .
          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-251">
           <a href="#cite_note-251">
            [247]
           </a>
          </sup>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <table class="wikitable">
       <tr>

          Six Flags Hurricane Harbor
         </a>
        </td>

         </a>
        </td>

        </td>
       </tr>

        </td>

      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="In_New_York_State">
        In New York State
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York_metropolitan_area&amp;action=edit&amp;section=49" title="Edit section: In New York State">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Playland_(New_York)" title="Playland (New York)">
        Playland
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Rye,_New_York" title="Rye, New York">
        Rye
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Westchester_County" title="Westchester County">
        Westchester County
       </a>
      </p>
      <p>
       Plans were unveiled by New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg on September 27, 2012 for the
       <a href="/wiki/New_York_Wheel" title="New York Wheel">
        New York Wheel
       </a>
       , a giant
       <a href="/wiki/Ferris_wheel" title="Ferris wheel">
        Ferris wheel
       </a>
       , to be built at the northern shore of Staten Island, overlooking the
       <a href="/wiki/Statue_of_Liberty" title="Statue of Liberty">
        Statue of Liberty
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/New_York_Harbor" title="New York Harbor">
        New York Harbor
       </a>
       , and the Lower Manhattan skyline.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-252">
        <a href="#cite_note-252">
         [248]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="In_Pennsylvania">
        In Pennsylvania
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York_metropolitan_area&amp;action=edit&amp;section=50" title="Edit section: In Pennsylvania">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Dorney_Park_%26_Wildwater_Kingdom" title="Dorney Park &amp; Wildwater Kingdom">
        Dorney Park &amp; Wildwater Kingdom
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Dorneyville,_Pennsylvania" title="Dorneyville, Pennsylvania">
        Dorneyville
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Lehigh_County,_Pennsylvania" title="Lehigh County, Pennsylvania">
        Lehigh County
       </a>
      </p>
      <p>
       Although the DP&amp;WWK complex is not planned as a theme park, it is nonetheless one of the largest amusement parks in Pennsylvania and draws substantially from Greater NYC since it is just off
       <a href="/wiki/Interstate_78" title="Interstate 78">
        Interstate 78
       </a>
       in a location just west of Allentown.
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Area_codes">
        Area codes
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York_metropolitan_area&amp;action=edit&amp;section=51" title="Edit section: Area codes">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <p>
       The area is served by at least 29 area codes:
      </p>
      <div class="div-col columns column-count column-count-2" style="-moz-column-count: 2; -webkit-column-count: 2; column-count: 2;">
       <ul>
        <li>
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Area_code_212" title="Area code 212">
          212
         </a>
         : Serves
         <a href="/wiki/Manhattan" title="Manhattan">
          Manhattan
         </a>
         and is
         <a href="/wiki/Overlay_plan" title="Overlay plan">
          overlaid
         </a>
         with
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Area_code_646" title="Area code 646">
          646
         </a>
         and
         <a href="/wiki/Area_code_917" title="Area code 917">
          917
         </a>
         .
        </li>
        <li>
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Area_code_718" title="Area code 718">
          718
         </a>
         : Serves all other boroughs of New York City and is overlaid with
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Area_code_347" title="Area code 347">
          347
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/Area_code_917" title="Area code 917">
          917
         </a>
         , and
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Area_code_929" title="Area code 929">
          929
         </a>
         .
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Area_code_917" title="Area code 917">
          917
         </a>
         : Serves all of New York City.
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Area_code_516" title="Area code 516">
          516
         </a>
         : Serves
         <a href="/wiki/Nassau_County,_New_York" title="Nassau County, New York">
          Nassau County
         </a>
         .
        </li>
        <li>
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Area_code_631" title="Area code 631">
          631
         </a>
         : Serves
         <a href="/wiki/Suffolk_County,_New_York" title="Suffolk County, New York">
          Suffolk County
         </a>
         .
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Area_code_914" title="Area code 914">
          914
         </a>
         : Serves
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Westchester_County" title="Westchester County">
          Westchester County
         </a>
         .
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Area_code_845" title="Area code 845">
          845
         </a>
         : Serves the Hudson Valley counties of Southern New York State.
        </li>
        <li>
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Area_code_570_and_272" title="Area code 570 and 272">
          570 &amp; 272
         </a>
         : Serves Northeastern
         <a href="/wiki/Pennsylvania" title="Pennsylvania">
          Pennsylvania
         </a>
         .
        </li>
        <li>
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Area_code_203_and_475" title="Area code 203 and 475">
          203 &amp; 475
         </a>
         : Serves Southwestern
         <a href="/wiki/Connecticut" title="Connecticut">
          Connecticut
         </a>
         ,
        </li>
        <li>
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Area_code_860_and_959" title="Area code 860 and 959">
          860 &amp; 959
         </a>
         : Serves the rest of Connecticut not served by 203 or 475.
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Area_codes_201_and_551" title="Area codes 201 and 551">
          201
         </a>
         : Serves most of Bergen County, as well as parts of Essex, Hudson, and Passaic in Northern New Jersey, and is overlaid with
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Area_code_551" title="Area code 551">
          551
         </a>
         .
        </li>
        <li>
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Area_code_973" title="Area code 973">
          973
         </a>
         : Serves portions of Bergen, Essex, Hudson, Morris, Passaic, Sussex, and portions of Union County in New Jersey, and is overlaid with
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Area_code_862" title="Area code 862">
          862
         </a>
         .
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Area_code_908" title="Area code 908">
          908
         </a>
         : Serves communities in Union County, Somerset County, northern parts of Middlesex County, Hunterdon County, Warren County, and Morris County as well as some cell phones in Monmouth County in New Jersey.
        </li>
        <li>
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Area_code_732" title="Area code 732">
          732
         </a>
         : Serves Middlesex County, Somerset County, portions of Union County, and Monmouth and northern Ocean counties in New Jersey; overlaid with
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Area_code_848" title="Area code 848">
          848
         </a>
         .
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Area_code_609" title="Area code 609">
          609
         </a>
         : Serves Mercer County and parts of Middlesex, Monmouth, and Ocean Counties.
        </li>
        <li>
         <a href="/wiki/Area_codes_610_and_484" title="Area codes 610 and 484">
          610 &amp; 484
         </a>
         : Serve most of the Lehigh Valley and portions of Carbon and Monroe Counties in Pennsylvania.
        </li>
        <li>
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Area_codes_215_and_267" title="Area codes 215 and 267">
          215 &amp; 267
         </a>
         : Serve the southernmost part of Lehigh County in Pennsylvania.
        </li>
       </ul>
      </div>

      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">
        Notes
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_York_metropolitan_area&amp;action=edit&amp;section=53" title="Edit section: Notes">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: lower-alpha;">
       <div class="mw-references-wrap">
        <ol class="references">
         <li id="cite_note-76">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-76">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           Mean monthly maxima and minima (i.e. the expected highest and lowest temperature readings at any point during the year or given month) calculated based on data at said location from 1981 to 2010.
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-78">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-78">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           Official weather observations for Central Park were conducted at the Arsenal at Fifth Avenue and 64th Street from 1869 to 1919, and at Belvedere Castle since 1919.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-77">
            <a href="#cite_note-77">
             [76]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-82">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-82">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           Mean monthly maxima and minima (i.e. the highest and lowest temperature readings during an entire month or year) calculated based on data at said location from 1981 to 2010.
          </span>
         </li>
         <li id="cite_note-83">
          <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
           <b>
            <a href="#cite_ref-83">
             ^
            </a>
           </b>
          </span>
          <span class="reference-text">
           Official records for Allentown were kept at Allentown Gas Company from March 1922 to December 1943, and at Lehigh Valley Int'l since January 1944. For more information, see
           <a class="external text" href="http://threadex.rcc-acis.org" rel="nofollow">
            ThreadEx
           </a>
           .
          </span>
         </li>
        </ol>
       </div>
      </div>

        <li id="cite_note-FastPaceNYC1-31">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-FastPaceNYC1_31-0">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation news">
           Poliak, Shira.
           <a class="external text" href="http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/2009-11-19/features/0911180065_1_new-yorkers-fast-paced-big-apple" rel="nofollow">
            "Adjusting To New York City"
           </a>
           .
           <i>
            Sun Sentinel
           </i>
           <span class="reference-accessdate">
            . Retrieved
            <span class="nowrap">
             November 1,
            </span>
            2015
           </span>
           .
           <q>
            Additionally, the fast-paced lifestyle of New York City demands adjusting.
           </q>
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Sun+Sentinel&amp;rft.atitle=Adjusting+To+New+York+City&amp;rft.aulast=Poliak&amp;rft.aufirst=Shira&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Farticles.sun-sentinel.com%2F2009-11-19%2Ffeatures%2F0911180065_1_new-yorkers-fast-paced-big-apple&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANew+York+metropolitan+area">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>

           <a href="#cite_ref-34">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">

           Plan your visit
          </a>
          ,
          <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">
           United Nations
          </a>
          . Accessed February 9, 2017. "The Headquarters of the United Nations is located in New York City, along the East River. When you pass through the gates of the United Nations visitors’ entrance, you enter an international territory. This 18-acre site does not belong to just one country, but to all countries that have joined the Organization; currently, the United Nations has 193 Member States."

          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-42">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation web">
           <a class="external text" href="http://www.businessinsider.com/top-8-cities-by-gdp-china-vs-the-us-2011-8" rel="nofollow">

         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-102">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation web">

          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=American+FactFinder&amp;rft.au=U.S.+Census+Bureau&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Ffactfinder.census.gov%2Ffaces%2Fnav%2Fjsf%2Fpages%2Fsearchresults.xhtml%3Frefresh%3Dt%26keepList%3Dt&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANew+York+metropolitan+area">
           <span style="display:none;">

          <span class="error citation-comment" style="font-size:100%">
           Missing or empty
           <code style="color:inherit; border:inherit; padding:inherit;">
            |title=
           </code>
           (
           <a href="/wiki/Help:CS1_errors#citation_missing_title" title="Help:CS1 errors">

        <li id="cite_note-114">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-114">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation news">
           Kirk Semple (June 23, 2011).
           <a class="external text" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/24/nyregion/asian-new-yorkers-asian-new-yorkers-seek-power-to-match-surging-numbers.html" rel="nofollow">
            "Asian New Yorkers Seek Power to Match Numbers"
           </a>
           .
           <i>
            <a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">
             The New York Times
            </a>
           </i>
           <span class="reference-accessdate">
            . Retrieved
            <span class="nowrap">
             July 5,
            </span>
            2011
           </span>
           .
           <q>
            Asians, a group more commonly associated with the West Coast, are surging in New York, where they have long been eclipsed in the city's kaleidoscopic racial and ethnic mix. For the first time, according to census figures released in the spring, their numbers have topped one million—nearly 1 in 8 New Yorkers—which is more than the Asian population in the cities of San Francisco and Los Angeles combined.
           </q>
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+New+York+Times&amp;rft.atitle=Asian+New+Yorkers+Seek+Power+to+Match+Numbers&amp;rft.date=2011-06-23&amp;rft.au=Kirk+Semple&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.nytimes.com%2F2011%2F06%2F24%2Fnyregion%2Fasian-new-yorkers-asian-new-yorkers-seek-power-to-match-surging-numbers.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANew+York+metropolitan+area">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-115">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-115">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation web">
           <a class="external text" href="http://www.ameredia.com/resources/demographics/asian_american.html" rel="nofollow">
            "Asian American Statistics"
           </a>
           . Améredia Incorporated
           <span class="reference-accessdate">
            . Retrieved
            <span class="nowrap">
             July 5,
            </span>
            2011
           </span>
           .
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Asian+American+Statistics&amp;rft.pub=Am%C3%A9redia+Incorporated&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.ameredia.com%2Fresources%2Fdemographics%2Fasian_american.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ANew+York+metropolitan+area">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>

        </li>

         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-QueensMostDiverseWorld1_116-0">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation news">
           Christine Kim; Demand Media.
           <a class="external text" href="http://traveltips.usatoday.com/queens-new-york-sightseeing-107156.html" rel="nofollow">
            "Queens, New York, Sightseeing"
           </a>

           <i>

           </i>

                <span class="flagicon">
                 <a href="/wiki/Egypt" title="Egypt">
                  <img alt="Egypt" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Flag_of_Egypt.svg/23px-Flag_of_Egypt.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Flag_of_Egypt.svg/35px-Flag_of_Egypt.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Flag_of_Egypt.svg/45px-Flag_of_Egypt.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>

                </span>
                Cairo
                <br/>
                15
                <span class="flagicon">
